question: Question 81 For a two-dimensional flow, the velocity field is [latex]\vec{u}=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\hat{i}+\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\hat{j}[/latex], where [latex]\hat{i}[/latex]  and [latex]\hat{j}[/latex]  are the basis vectors in the x-y Cartesian coordinate system. Identify the CORRECT statements from below. (1)The flow is incompressible (2)The flow is unsteady. (3) y-component of acceleration, [latex]a_{y}=\frac{-y}{(x^{2}+y^{2})^{2}}[/latex] (4)  x-component of acceleration,[latex]a_{x}=\frac{-(x+y)}{(x^{2}+y^{2})^{2}}[/latex]
solution: For [latex]2 \mathrm{D}[/latex] -flow velocity field is: [latex] \begin{aligned} \vec{V}&=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \hat{i}+\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \hat{j}\\ so \quad u&=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} and v=\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \\ a_{x} &=u \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+v \frac{\partial u}{\partial y} \\ &=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left[\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right] \\ &+\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left[\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right] \\ &= \frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\left[\frac{x(-2 x)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{1}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right]\\ &+\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \left[\frac{x(2 y)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}}\right]\\ &=\frac{-2 x^{3}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}+\frac{x}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}}\\ &+ \frac{2xy^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}\\ &=\frac{-2 x^{3}+x\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)-2 x y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}} \\ &=\frac{-2 x^{3}+x^{3}+x y^{2}-2 x y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}\\ &=\frac{-x^{3}-x y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}} \\ &=\frac{-x\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} a_{x} &=\frac{x}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}} \\ a_{y} &=u \frac{\partial v}{\partial x}+u \frac{\partial v}{\partial y} \\ &=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left[\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right] \\& +\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left[\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right] \\ &=\frac{x}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \frac{(-2 x y)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}}\\& +\frac{y}{x^{2}+y^{2}} \times\left[\frac{-2 y^{2}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{1}{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right]\\ &=\frac{-2 x^{2} y}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}+\frac{2 y^{3}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}\\&+\frac{y}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}} \\ &=\frac{-2 x^{2} y-2 y^{3}+y\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}} \\ &=\frac{-x^{2} y-y^{3}}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}}=\frac{y\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{3}} \\ a_{y}&=\frac{-y}{\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 82 The water jet exiting from a stationary tank through a circular opening of diameter 300 mm impinges on a rigid wall as shown in the figure. Neglect all minor losses and assume the water level in the tank to remain constant. The net horizontal force experienced by the wall is ___________ kN. Density of water is 1000 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]. Acceleration due to gravity g = 10 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex].
solution: Diameter of jet, [latex] d = 300\mathrm{mm} = 0.30 \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad [/latex]Cross-section area, [latex] \begin{aligned} a &=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2}=\frac{3.14}{4} \times(0.30)^{2} \\ &=0.07065 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \text{Jet Velocity: }V \;&=\sqrt{2 g h}\\ &=\sqrt{2 \times 10 \times 6.2} = 11.135\mathrm{m}/\mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Net horizontal force [latex] \begin{aligned} F &=m[V-0] \\ &=\rho a V \times V \\ &=\rho a V^{2} \\ &=1000 \times 0.07065 \times(11.135)^{2} \\ &=8759.76 \mathrm{N} \\ &=8.76 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 83 Consider a fully developed steady laminar flow of an incompressible fluid with viscosity [latex]\mu[/latex] through a circular pipe of radius R. Given that the velocity at a radial location of R/2 from the centerline of the pipe is [latex]U_{1}[/latex], the shear stress at the wall is [latex]K\mu U_{1}/R[/latex], where K is __________
solution: Shear stress at the wall, [latex] \tau_{0}=\tau_{\max }=\frac{k \mu U_{1}}{R}[/latex] We know that the velocity at any point for laminar flow through pipe, [latex] \begin{aligned} u&=-\frac{1}{4 \mu}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right)\left(R^{2}-r^{2}\right)\\ \mathrm{At} \quad r&=\frac{R}{2}, u=U_{1}\\ \therefore \quad U_{1} &=-\frac{1}{4 \mu}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right)\left(R^{2}-\frac{R^{2}}{4}\right) \\ &=-\frac{1}{4 \mu}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right) \frac{3}{4} R^{2} \\ &=-\frac{3}{16 \mu}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right) R^{2}\\ \therefore \tau_{0}&=-\frac{K \mu}{R} \times \frac{3}{16 \mu}\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right) R^{2}\\ \tau_{0}&=-\frac{3}{16} K\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right) R\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] We know that maximum shear stress at wall. [latex] \tau_{0}=-\frac{R \partial p}{\partial} \frac{\partial p}{\partial x}[/latex] [latex] \therefore-\frac{3}{16} K\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\right) R=-\frac{R}{2} \frac{\partial p}{\partial x} [/latex] [latex] \text{or}K=\frac{8}{3}=2.66[/latex]

question: Question 84 The blade and fluid velocities for an axial turbine are as shown in the figure. The magnitude of absolute velocity at entry is 300 m/s at an angle of [latex]65^{\circ}[/latex] to the axial direction, while the magnitude of the absolute velocity at exit is 150 m/s. The exit velocity vector has a component in the downward direction. Given that the axial (horizontal) velocity is the same at entry and exit, the specific work (in kJ/kg) is__________
solution: Given data: Axial (horizontal) velocity is the same at entry and exit. [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{1}=300 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \theta_{1}=65^{\circ} \\ V_{2}=150 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}, u=150 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Given condition, [latex] V_{1} \cos 65^{\circ}=V_{2} \cos \theta_{0}[/latex] [latex] 300 \cos 65^{\circ}=150 \times \cos \theta_{0}[/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad\cos \theta_{0}=0.8452 [/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad \theta_{0}=32.30^{\circ}[/latex] Specific work, [latex] \begin{aligned} w &=\left[V_{1} \sin 65^{\circ}-\left(-V_{2} \sin 32.30^{\circ}\right)\right] u \\ &=\left[300 \sin 65^{\circ}+150 \sin 32.30^{\circ}\right]\times150 \\ &=52806.77 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg} \\ &=52.80 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 For a certain two-dimensional incompressible flow, velocity field is given by  [latex]2xy\hat{i}-y^{2}\hat{j}[/latex]. The streamlines for this flow are given by the family of curves
solution: [latex]\vec{v}=2 x y \hat{i}-y^{2} \hat{j}[/latex] where  [latex]u=2 x y[/latex] and [latex]v=-y^{2} [/latex] Equation of stream line, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d x}{u} &=\frac{d y}{v} \\ \frac{d x}{2 x y} &=\frac{d y}{-y^{2}} \\ \text{or}\quad \frac{d x}{2 x} &=-\frac{d y}{y} \end{aligned}[/latex] On integrating, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} \log _{e} x&=-\log _{e} y+\log _{e} c \\ \log _{e} x^{1 / 2}+\log _{e} y&=\log _{e} c \\ \log _{e} x^{1 / 2} y&=\log _{e} c \\ \text { or } \quad x^{1 / 2} y&=c \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 86 A channel of width 450 mm branches into two sub-channels having width 300 mm and 200 mm as shown in figure. If the volumetric flow rate (taking unit depth) of an incompressible flow through the main channel is 0.9 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s and the velocity in the sub-channel of width 200 mm is 3 m/s, the velocity in the sub-channel of width 300 mm is _____________ m/s. Assume both inlet and outlet to be at the same elevation.
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} b_{1}&=450 \mathrm{mm}=0.45 \mathrm{m} \\ b_{2}&=300 \mathrm{mm}=0.30 \mathrm{m} \\ b_{3}&=200 \mathrm{mm}=0.20 \mathrm{m} Depth: \quad h&=1 \mathrm{m} \\ Q_{1}&=0.9 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{3}&=3 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{2}&=? \end{aligned}[/latex] Apply equation of continuity, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} Q_{1}&=Q_{2}+Q_{3}\\ Q_{1}&=A_{2} V_{2}+A_{3} V_{3} \\ Q_{1}&=b_{2} h V_{2}+b_{3} h V_{3} \\ 0.9&=0.30 \times 1 \times V_{2}+0.20 \times 1 \times 3 \\ 0.9&=0.30 \mathrm{V}_{2}+0.60\\ or \quad 0.30 \mathrm{V}_{2}&=0.9-0.6=0.30 \\ or\qquad v_{2}=\frac{0.30}{0.30}&=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 Consider a frictionless, massless and leak-proof plug blocking a rectangular hole of dimensions  2R x L  at the bottom of an open tank as shown in the figure. The head of the plug has the shape of a semi-cylinder of radius R. The tank is filled with a liquid of density  [latex]\rho[/latex]  up to the tip of the plug. The gravitational acceleration is g. Neglect the effect of the atmospheric pressure. The force F required to hold the plug in its position
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Volume, } V_{total}&=2R \times L \times R\\ &=2R^2L\;\;...(i)\\ \text{Volume: }V_1&=\frac{1}{2}\times \pi R^2 \times L\;\;...(ii)\\ F&= \text{Weight of fluid}\\ &=[V_{total}-V_{1}]\rho g\\ &=\left [ 2R^2L-\frac{\pi R^2L}{2} \right ]\rho g\\ &=\left [ 1-\frac{\pi}{4} \right ]2R^2Lg\rho \\ &=2\rho R^2gL\left [ 1-\frac{\pi}{4} \right ] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 88 Consider fluid flow between two infinite horizontal plates which are parallel (the gap between them being 50 mm). The top plate is sliding parallel to the stationary bottom plate at a speed of 3 m/s. The flow between the plates is solely due to the motion of the top plate. The force per unit area (magnitude) required to maintain the bottom plate stationary is _________ [latex]N/m^{2}[/latex] Viscosity of the fluid [latex]\mu =0.44[/latex] kg/m-s and density [latex]\rho =888 kg/m^{3}[/latex].
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} h&=50 \mathrm{mm}=0.050 \mathrm{mm} \\ U&=3 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \mu&=0.44 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{ms} \\ \rho&=888 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Newton's law of viscosity, [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau &=\mu \frac{d u}{d y}=\frac{\mu U}{h} \\ &=\frac{0.44 \times 3}{0.050}=26.4 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 89 The large vessel shown in the figure contains oil and water. A body is submerged at the interface of oil and water such that 45 percent of its volume is in oil while the rest is in water. The density of the body is _________ [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]. The specific gravity of oil is 0.7 and density of water is 1000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex] . Acceleration due to gravity g = 10 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex]
solution: Let V= Volume of metalic body 45% of volume is in oil i.e.   [latex]V_{oil}=[/latex] 45% of V=0.45V and [latex]V_{ater}=[/latex] 0.55V For equilibrium condition, Net buoyant force [latex]=(F_B)_{water}+(F_B)_{oil}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} M_bg&=\rho _w V_{water}\;g+\rho _{oil}V_{oil}\;g \\ M_b&= \rho _w V_{water}+\rho _{oil}V_{oil}\\ \rho _b V&= \rho _w \times 0.55V+\rho _{oil} \times 0.45V\\ \rho _b&= \rho _w \times 0.55+\rho _{oil} \times 0.45\\ &=1000 \times 0.55+700 \times 0.45 \\ &= 865\;kg/m^3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 91 The volumetric flow rate (per unit depth) between two streamlines having stream functions [latex]\Psi_{1}[/latex] and [latex]\Psi_{2}[/latex]  is

Question 92 A steady laminar boundary layer is formed over a flat plate as shown in the figure. The free stream velocity of the fluid is [latex]U_{0}[/latex]. The velocity profile at the inlet a-b is uniform, while that at a downstream location c-d is given by [latex]u=U_{0}\left [ 2( \frac{y}{\delta }) -(\frac{y}\delta {})^{2}\right ][/latex] . The ratio of the mass flow rate, [latex]\dot{m}_{bd}[/latex]  leaving through the horizontal section b-d to that entering through the vertical section a-b is ___________
solution: [latex] U_{0}= [/latex] Velocity of free stream d= Boundary layer thickness at section c-d b= Width of the plate Velocity profile, [latex] u=U_{0}\left[2\left(\frac{y}{\delta}\right)-\left(\frac{y}{\delta}\right)^{2}\right][/latex] Mass flow rate through section a-b, [latex] \begin{aligned} \dot{m}_{\mathrm{ab}} &=\rho A U_{0} \\ &=\rho b \delta U_{0} \end{aligned}[/latex] Mass flow rate through section c-d [latex] \dot{m}_{c d}=\int_{0}^{\delta} \rho b d y U[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\int_{0}^{\delta} \rho b U_{0}\left[2 \frac{y}{\delta}-\left(\frac{y}{\delta}\right)^{2}\right] d y \\ m_{c d} &=\rho b U_{0}\left[\frac{2 y^{2}}{2 \delta}-\frac{y^{3}}{3 \delta^{2}}\right]_{0}^{\delta}\\ &=\rho b U_{0}\left[\frac{\delta^{2}}{\delta}-\frac{\delta^{3}}{3 \delta^{2}}\right]\\ &=\rho b U_{0}\left[\delta-\frac{\delta}{3}\right] \\ &=\rho b U_{0} \times \frac{2}{3} \delta \\ &=\frac{2}{3} \rho b \delta U_{0}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Mass flow rate through section b-d, [latex]\begin{aligned} \dot{m_{bd}} &=\dot{m_{ad}}- \dot{m_{cd}} \\ &= \rho b\delta U_0-\frac{2}{3}\rho b\delta U_0\\ &= \frac{\rho b\delta U_0}{3}\\ \frac{\dot{m_{bd}}}{\dot{m_{ab}}}&=\frac{\rho b\delta U_0}{3 \times \rho b\delta U_0}=\frac{1}{3}=0.333 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 93 Oil (kinematic viscosity, [latex]v_{oil}=1.0\times 10^{-5}m^{2}/s[/latex] ) flows through a pipe of 0.5 m diameter with a velocity of 10 m/s. Water (kinematic viscosity,[latex]v_{w}=0.89\times 10^{-6}m^{2}/s[/latex] ) is flowing through a model
pipe of diameter 20 mm. For satisfying the dynamic similarity, the velocity of water (in m/s)
is __________
solution: Given data: For prototype [latex] \begin{aligned} v_{p}&=1.0 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \\ d_{p}&=0.5 \mathrm{m} \\ V_{p}&=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ \text{For model}\\ v_{m}&=0.89 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \\ d_{m}&=20 \mathrm{mm}=0.02 \mathrm{m} \\ V_{m}&=? \end{aligned}[/latex] We know that Reynolds number, [latex] \begin{aligned} Re &=\frac{V d}{v} \\ (R e)_{m} &=(R e)_{p} \\ \frac{V_{m} d_{m}}{v_{m}} &=\frac{V_{p} d_{p}}{v_{p}} \\ \frac{V_{m} \times 0.02}{0.89 \times 10^{-6}} &=\frac{10 \times 0.5}{1.0 \times 10^{-5}} \\ \text{or }\quad V_{m} &=22.25 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] or The velocity of water is [latex]22.25 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question: Question 94 An inverted U-tube manometer is used to measure the pressure difference between two pipes A and B, as shown in the figure. Pipe A is carrying oil (specific gravity = 0.8) and pipe B is carrying water. The densities of air and water are 1.16kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex]  and 1000kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex], respectively. The pressure difference between pipes A and B is __________kPa. Acceleration due to gravity g = 10 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex] .
solution: Given data: Specific gravity of oil, [latex] s^{oil} = 0.8[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \rho_{\mathrm{oil}}=0.8 \times 1000=800 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Density of air: [latex]\rho_{\text {air }}=1.16 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] Density of water, [latex] \rho_{\text {water }}=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] Acceleration due to gravity, [latex] \begin{aligned} g &=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ h_{1} &=80 \mathrm{mm}=0.08 \mathrm{m} \\ h_{2} &=200 \mathrm{mm}=0.2 \mathrm{m} \\ h_{3} &=100 \mathrm{mm}=0.1 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Pressure at section 1 on left limb = Pressure at section 1 on right limb [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{A}-\rho_{\text {oil }} g h_{2}-\rho_{\text {air }} g h_{1}&=p_{B}-\rho_{\text {water }} g\left(h_{1}+h_{2}+h_{3})\right. \\ p_{A}-800 \times 10 \times 0.2&-1.16 \times 10 \times 0.08 =p_{B}-\\ &1000 \times 10(0.08+0.2+0.1) \\ p_{A}-1600-0.928&=p_{B}-3800\\ p_{A}-p_{B} &=-2199.07 \mathrm{Pa} \\ &=-2.199 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 95 Consider two hydraulic turbines having identical specific speed and effective head at the inlet. If the speed ratio (N1/N2) of the two turbines is 2, then the respective power ratio (P1/P2) is _____________
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{s 1} &=N_{s 2} \\ H_{1} &=H_{2} \\ \frac{N_{1}}{N_{2}} &=2 \end{aligned}\\ \text{We know that specific speed of the turbine,}\\ \begin{aligned} N_{s}&=\frac{N \sqrt{P}}{H^{5 / 4}}\\ \left(N_{s}\right)_{1} &=\left(N_{s}\right)_{2} \\ \frac{N_{1} \sqrt{P_{1}}}{H_{1}^{5 / 4}} &=\frac{N_{2} \sqrt{P_{2}}}{H_{2}^{5 / 4}} \\ N_{1} \sqrt{P_{1}} &=N_{2} \sqrt{P_{2}} \qquad\therefore H_{1}= h_{2} \\ \text{or}\quad\sqrt{\frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}}} &=\frac{N_{2}}{N_{1}}\\ \text{or}\quad\frac{P_{1}}{P_{2}} &=\left(\frac{N_{2}}{N_{1}}\right)^{2} \\ &=\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 97 The instantaneous stream-wise velocity of a turbulent flow is given as follows: [latex]u( x,y,z,t )=\bar{u}(x,y,z)+{u}'(x,y,z,t)[/latex] The time-average of the fluctuating velocity [latex]{u}'(x,y,z,t)[/latex]  is
solution: Instantaneous velocity : [latex] u=\bar{u}+u^{\prime} [/latex] The time-average of the fluctuating velocity [latex] \begin{aligned} \bar{u}^{\prime} &=\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} u^{\prime} d t \\ &=\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T}(u-\bar{u}) d t \\ &=\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} u d T-\frac{1}{T} \bar{u} \int_{0}^{T} d t=\bar{u}-\frac{\bar{U}}{T} T \\ &=\bar{u}-\bar{u}=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 Which of the following statements are TRUE, when the cavitation parameter [latex]\sigma =0[/latex] ? (i) the local pressure is reduced to vapor pressure (ii) cavitation starts (iii) boiling of liquid starts (iv) cavitation stops
solution: Cavitation parameter: [latex] \sigma=0 [/latex] It means: (i) The local pressure is reduce to vapour pressure (ii) Cavitation strarts (iii) Boiling of liquid starts

question: Question 99 A Prandtl tube (Pitot-static tube with C=1) is used to measure the velocity of water. The differential manometer reading is 10 mm of liquid column with a relative density of 10. Assuming  g = 9.8 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex], the velocity of water (in m/s) is ________
solution: Given data: [latex]\begin{aligned} C &=1 \\ x &=10 \mathrm{mm} \text { of liquid }=0.01 \mathrm{m} \text { of liquid } \\ S &=10 \\ \rho_{\text {mano }} &=10 \times 1000=10000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ g &=9.8 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ h &=x\left[\frac{\rho_{\operatorname{man}}}{\rho_{\text {water }}}-1\right]=0.01\left[\frac{1000}{1000}-1\right] \\ &=0.09 \mathrm{m} \text { of water } \end{aligned}[/latex] Velocity of water [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=C \sqrt{2 g h}=1 \sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 0.09} \\ &=1.328 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

The correct expressions for total flow rate (Q) and frictional head loss across the two ends ([latex]h_{L}[/latex] ) are

Q=Q_{1}+Q_{2}+Q_{2}[/latex] Head loss: [latex]h_{L}=h_{L_{1}}=h_{L_{2}}=h_{L_{3}} [/latex]

question: Question 101 Couette flow is characterized by
solution: Couette flow In fluid dynamics, couette flow is the laminar flow of a viscous fluid in the space between two parallel plates, one of which is moving relative to the other. The flow is driven by virtue of viscous drag force acting on the fluid and the applied pressure gradient parallel to the plates.

options.A: steady, incompressible, laminar flow through a straight circular pipe

question: Question 102 For a fully developed laminar flow of water (dynamic viscosity 0.001 Pa-s) through a pipe of radius 5 cm, the axial pressure gradient is -10 Pa/m. The magnitude of axial velocity (in m/s) at a radial location of 0.2 cm is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mu &=0.001 \mathrm{Pa}-\mathrm{s} \\ R &=5 \mathrm{cm}=0.05 \mathrm{m} \\ \frac{\partial p}{\partial x} &=-10 \mathrm{Pa} / \mathrm{m} \\ r &=0.2 \mathrm{cm}=0.002 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] For incompressible laminar flow throughpipe Local velocity, [latex] \begin{aligned} u &=-\frac{1}{4 \mu} \frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\left[R^{2}-r^{2}\right] \\ &=-\frac{1}{4 \times 0.001} \times(-10)\left[(0.05)^{2}-(0.002)^{2}\right] \\ &=6.24 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 103 The head loss for a laminar incompressible flow through a horizontal circular pipe is [latex]h_{1}[/latex]. Pipe length and fluid remaining the same, if the average flow velocity doubles and the pipe diameter reduces to half its previous value, the head loss is[latex]h_{2}[/latex] . The ratio [latex]\frac{h_{2}}{h_{1}}[/latex]  is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Head loss: } & h_{f}=\frac{32 \mu \bar{u} L}{\rho g D^{2}} \\ & h_{1}=\frac{32 \mu \bar{u} L}{\rho g D^{2}}\\ \text{and }\quad h_{2}&=\frac{32 \mu \times 2 \bar{u} L}{\rho g(D / 2)^{2}} \\ &=\frac{32 \mu 2 \bar{u} L \times 4}{\rho g D^{2}}=\frac{8 \times 32 \mu \pi L}{\rho g D^{2}} \\ \frac{h_{2}}{h_{1}} &=\frac{8 \times 32 \mu \bar{u} L}{\rho g D^{2}} \times \frac{\rho g D^{2}}{32 \mu \bar{U} L}=8 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 105 If the fluid velocity for a potential flow is given by [latex]V(x,y)=u(x,y)i+v(x,y)j[/latex]  with usual notations, then the slope of the potential line at [latex](x,y)[/latex]  is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} d \phi&=\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x} d x+\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial y} d y\\ \therefore \qquad \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial x}&=-u\\ \frac{\partial \phi}{\partial y}&=-v \\ \therefore \qquad d \phi&=-u d x-v d y \\ \text { If } \phi&=\text { constant, } d \phi=0 \\ \therefore \quad\left(\frac{d y}{d x}\right)_{\phi}&=-\frac{u}{v} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 106 Water ([latex]\rho =1000 kg/m^{3}[/latex]) flows through a venturimeter with inlet diameter 80 mm and throat diameter 40 mm. The inlet and throat gauge pressures are measured to be 400 kPa and 130 kPa respectively. Assuming the venturimeter to be horizontal and neglecting friction, the inlet velocity (in m/s)  is _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho &=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ d_{1} &=80 \mathrm{mm}=0.08 \mathrm{mm} \\ d_{2} &=40 \mathrm{mm}=0.04 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1}&=400 \mathrm{kPa}=400 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{Pa} \\ p_{2}&=130 \mathrm{kPa}=130 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{Pa} \end{aligned} [/latex] Applying Bernoullis equation between sections 1 and 2 [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}&+z_{1}=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{2} \\ \text{where }z_{1}&=z_{1} \text{ for horizontal pipe}\\ \therefore \quad \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}&=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g} \\ or \quad \frac{p_{1}-p_{2}}{\rho g}&=\frac{V_{2}^{2}-V_{1}^{2}}{2 g} \\ or \quad \frac{p_{1}-p_{2}}{\rho}&=\frac{V_{2}^{2}-V_{2}^{2}}{2} \quad\ldots(i)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying continuity equation between sections and 2 [latex]\begin{aligned} A_{1} V_{1}&=A_{2} V_{2} \\ \frac{\pi}{4} d_{1}^{2} V_{1}&=\frac{\pi}{2} d_{2}^{2} V_{2}\\ \text{or }\quad d_{1}^{2} V_{1}&=d_{2}^{2} V_{2}\\ \text{or }\quad V_{2}&=\left(\frac{d_{1}}{d_{2}}\right)^{2} V_{1}=\left(\frac{0.08}{0.04}\right)^{2} V_{1} \\ V_{2}&=4 V_{1}\\ \text{Substituting } V_{2}&=4 V_{1} \text{ in Eq. }( i ),\text{ we get}\\ \frac{400 \times 10^{3}-130 \times 10^{3}}{1000}&=\frac{\left(4 V_{1}\right)^{2}-V_{1}^{2}}{2} \\ 540&=16 \mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}-V_{1}^{2} \\ 540&=15 \mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}\\ or \quad V_{1}^{2}&=36\\ or \quad V_{1}&=6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 107 Air ([latex]\rho =1.2 kg/m^{3}[/latex] and kinematic viscosity, [latex]v=2\times 10^{-5}m^{2}/s[/latex] ) with a velocity of 2 m/s flows over the top surface of a flat plate of length 2.5 m.  If the average value of friction coefficient is [latex]C_{f}=\frac{1.328}{\sqrt{R_{e_{x}}}}[/latex],  the total drag force (in N) per unit width of the plate is _______
solution: Drag force = average shear stress x area where [latex]\bar{\tau}=[/latex] average shear stress [latex] =\bar{C}_{f} \times \frac{\rho U_{\infty}^{2}}{2} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{1.328}{\sqrt{\mathrm{Re}_{L}}} \times \frac{\rho U_{0}^{2}}{2} [/latex] [latex] Re_{L}= [/latex]Local Reynold's number at trailing edge, [latex] =\frac{U_{\infty} L}{\mu}[/latex] [latex] =\frac{2 \times 2.5 \times 1.2}{1.2 \times 2 \times 10^{-5}} [/latex] [latex] =2.5 \times 10^{5}(\text { laminar flow })[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Drag force: } F_{D} &=\bar{\tau} \times A \\ &=\frac{1.328}{\sqrt{2.5 \times 10^{5}}} \times \frac{1.2 \times 2^{2}}{2} \times(2.5 \times 1) \\ &=0.0159 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 108 The velocity field of an incompressible flow is given by [latex]V=(a_{1}x+a_{2}y+a_{3}z)i[/latex] + [latex] (b_{1}x+b_{2}y+b_{3}z)j[/latex] + [latex] (c_{1}x+c_{2}y+c_{3}z)k[/latex] , where [latex]a_{1}= 2[/latex]  and [latex]c_{3}= -4[/latex]. The value of [latex]b_{2}[/latex] is ___________
solution: From continuity equation [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial v}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial w}{\partial z} &=0 \\ a_{1}+b_{2}+c_{2} &=0 \\ 2+b_{2}-4 &=0\\ \text{or}\quad b_{2}=4-2&=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 109 Match the following pairs:
solution: [latex]  \nabla \times \vec{V}=0 [/latex] Irrotional flow [latex]  \nabla \cdot \vec{V}=0 \quad [/latex] Incompressible continuity eq. [latex]  \frac{D \vec{V}}{D t}=0 [/latex] Zero acceleration of fluid particle [latex] \frac{\partial \vec{V}}{d t}=0 \quad [/latex] Steady flow

question: Question 110 Consider fully developed flow in a circular pipe with negligible entrance length effects. Assuming the mass flow rate, density and friction factor to be constant, if the length of the pipe  is doubled and the diameter is halved, the head loss due to friction will increase by a factor of
solution: Head loss due to friction, [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{f}&=\frac{f L V^{2}}{2 g d}\\ &\text{Mass flow rate,}\\ m&=\rho A V=\rho \times \frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} V\\ or\quad V&=\frac{4 m}{\rho \pi d^{2}} \\ \therefore \quad h_{f}&=\frac{f L}{2 g d} \times \frac{16 m^{2}}{\rho^{2} \pi^{2} d^{4}}\\ &=\frac{8 f m^{2}}{\rho^{2} \pi^{2}} \times \frac{L}{d^{5}} \\ &=C \times \frac{L}{d^{5}} \text { where } C=\frac{8 f m^{2}}{\rho^{2} \pi^{2}} \\ h_{f_{1}}&=C \times \frac{L}{d^{5}}\\ and\quad h_{2} &=C \times \frac{2 L}{(d / 2)^{5}}=\frac{C \times 2 L}{\frac{d^{5}}{2^{5}}} \\ &=\frac{C \times 2 \times 2^{5} L}{d^{5}}=\frac{C \times 64 L}{d^{5}} \\ h_{1 / 2} &=64 h_{11} \end{aligned}[/latex] The head loss due to friction will increase by a factor of 64

question: Question 111 Consider a velocity field [latex]\vec{V}=K(y\hat{i}+x\hat{k})[/latex] where K is a constant. The vorticity, [latex]\Omega_{Z}[/latex], is
solution: Velocity vector [latex] \begin{aligned} \vec{V} &=K(y \hat{i}+x \hat{k}) \\ &=K y \hat{i}+K x \hat{k} \end{aligned}[/latex] where, [latex] u=K y, v=0 \text { and } w=K x [/latex] Vorticity about z-axis, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Omega_{z} &=\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial u}{\partial y} \\ \frac{\partial v}{\partial x} &=0, \quad \frac{\partial u}{\partial y}=K \\ \therefore \quad \Omega_{z} &=0-K=-K \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 112 Consider the following statements regarding streamline(s): (i) It is a continuous line such that the tangent at any point on it shows the velocity vector at that point (ii) There is no flow across streamlines (iii) [latex]\frac{dx}{u}=\frac{dy}{v}=\frac{dz}{w}[/latex] is the differential equation of a streamline, where u, v and w are velocities in directions x, y and z, respectively (iv) In an unsteady flow, the path of a particle is a streamline Which one of the following combinations of the statements is true?
solution: Stream lines : Stream lines are the Family of curves that are instantaneously tangent to the velocity vector of the flow. These shows the direction a fluid element will travel in at any point. Path lines :- Path lines are the trajectories that individual fluid particles follow.
