question: Question 114 A flow field which has only convective acceleration is
solution: Total acceleration, [latex] \frac{D V}{D t}=\frac{\partial V}{\partial t}+V \cdot \nabla V [/latex] [latex] V \cdot \nabla V \rightarrow [/latex] Convective acceleration [latex] \frac{\partial V}{\partial t} \rightarrow [/latex] Local acceleration In steady non-uniform flow, conditions change from point to point in the stream but do not change with time.

question: Question 115 At the inlet of an axial impulse turbine rotor, the blade linear speed is 25 m/s, the magnitude of absolute velocity is 100 m/s and the angle between them is 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The relative velocity and the axial component of velocity remain the same between the inlet and outlet of the blades. The blade inlet and outlet velocity triangles are shown in the figure. Assuming no losses, the specific work (in J/kg) is _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} u &=25 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{i} &=100 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \alpha_{i} &=25^{\circ} \\ V_{r_{i}}=V_{r_{0}} &=78 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{0} &=58.6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{t_{i}} &=V_{r_{U}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \cos \alpha_{i} &=\frac{V_{w i}}{V_{i}} \\ \cos 25^{\circ} &=\frac{V_{w i}}{100} \\ or \quad V_{w_{i}}&=100 \times \cos 25^{\circ}=90.36 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ \sin \alpha_{i} &=\frac{V_{f_{i}}}{V_{i}} \\ \sin 25^{\circ} &=\frac{V_{f_{i}}}{100} \\ or \quad V_{f_{i}}&=100 \times \sin 25^{\circ}=42.26 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{w_{0}} &=\sqrt{V_{0}^{2}-V_{f_{0}}^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{(58.6)^{2}-(42.26)^{2}}=40.59 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \text{Specific work,}\\ w&=\left(V_{w_{i}}+V_{w_{0}}\right) u \\ &=(90.63+40.59) \times 25 \\ &=3280.5 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 116 A fluid of dynamic viscosity [latex]2\times 10^{-5}[/latex] kg/m.s and density 1 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex] flows with an average velocity of 1 m/s through a long duct of rectangular (25 mm x 15 mm) cross-section. Assuming laminar flow, the pressure drop (in Pa) in the fully developed region per meter length of the duct is _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} \mu&=2 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{ms} \\ \rho&=1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \bar{u}&=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] a=25 \mathrm{mm}=0.025 \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] b=15 \mathrm{mm}=0.015 \mathrm{m} [/latex] Characteristic diameter, [latex] D_{c}=\frac{4 A}{P}[/latex] where [latex] \qquad A=a \times b,[/latex] cross-section area [latex] =0.025 \times 0.015 [/latex] [latex] =3.75 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex] and [latex] \qquad \mathrm{P}=2(\mathrm{a}+\mathrm{b}),[/latex] wetted perimeter [latex] =2(0.025+0.015)=0.08 \mathrm{m}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \qquad D_{c}=\frac{4 \times 3.74 \times 10^{-4}}{0.08}=0.0187 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Pressure drop, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta p &=\frac{32 \mu \bar{u} L}{D_{c}^{2}} \\ \frac{\Delta p}{L} &=\frac{32 \mu \bar{u}}{D_{c}^{2}} \\ &=\frac{32 \times 2 \times 10^{-5} \times 1}{(0.0187)^{2}} \\ &=1.83 \mathrm{Pa} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 117 A siphon is used to drain water from a large tank as shown in the figure below. Assume that the level of water is maintained constant. Ignore frictional effect due to viscosity and losses at entry and exit. At the exit of the siphon, the velocity of water is
solution: Applying Bernoulli's equation between P and R, [latex] \frac{P_{a t m}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{p}^{2}}{2 g}+Z_{p}=\frac{V_{R}^{2}}{2 g}+Z_{R}+\frac{P_{a t m}}{\rho g} [/latex] or [latex] \frac{v_{R}^{2}}{2 g}=\left(Z_{p}-Z_{R}\right) [/latex] [latex] \qquad \left(\because V_{P}=0 \text{for still water}) \right.[/latex] [latex] \therefore \qquad V_{R}=\sqrt{2 g\left(Z_{P}-Z_{R}\right)}[/latex]

question: Question 118 Consider the turbulent flow of a fluid through a circular pipe of diameter, D.  Identify the correct pair of statements. I. The fluid is well-mixed II. The fluid is unmixed III. [latex]R_{e_{D}} \lt 2300[/latex] IV. [latex]R_{e_{D}} \gt 2300[/latex]
solution: For turbulent flow, [latex] \mathrm{Re}>2300 [/latex] Turbulent flow is considered as well mixed flow.

question: Question 119 Consider laminar flow of water over a flat plate of length 1 m. If the  boundary layer thickness at a distance of 0.25 m from the leading edge of the plate is 8 mm, the boundary layer thickness  (in mm), at a distance of 0.75 m, is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \delta &\propto \sqrt{x} \\ \frac{\delta_{2}}{\delta_{1}}&=\sqrt{\frac{x_{2}}{x_{1}}}=\sqrt{\frac{0.75}{0.25}}=\sqrt{3} \\ \therefore \qquad \delta_{2}&=\delta_{1} \sqrt{3}=1.732 \times 8=13.8564 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 120 Water flows through a 10 mm diameter and 250 m long smooth pipe at an average velocity of  0.1 m/s. The density and the viscosity of water are 997 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]  and [latex]855\times 10^{-6}N.s/m^{2}[/latex] , respectively. Assuming fully-developed flow, the pressure drop (in Pa) in the pipe is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} D&=10 \mathrm{mm}=0.01 \mathrm{m} \\ L&=250 \mathrm{m} \\ \bar{u}&=0.1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \rho&=997 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \mu &= 855 \times 10^{-6}Ns/m^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Pressure drop in the pipe, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta p&=\frac{32 \mu \bar{u} L}{D^{2}} \\ &=\frac{32 \times 855 \times 10^{-6} \times 0.1 \times 250}{(0.01)^{2}} \ &=6840 \mathrm{Pa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 121 A spherical balloon with a diameter of 10 m, shown in the figure below is used for advertisements. The balloon is filled with helium ([latex]R_{He}=2.08 kJ/kg.K[/latex] ) at ambient conditions of 15[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and 100 kPa. Assuming no disturbances due to wind, the maximum allowable weight (in newton) of balloon material and rope required to avoid the fall of the balloon ([latex]R_{air}=0.289 kJ/kg.K[/latex] ) is _______
solution: Step-I: Mass of balloon [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Volume: } \quad V &=\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}=\frac{4 \times 3.14 \times 5^{3}}{3} \\ &=523.33 \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \rho_{He} &=\frac{P}{R T}=\frac{100 \times 10^{3}}{2080 \times 288} \\ &=0.16693 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \text { Total mass } &=0.16693 \times 523.33 \\ &=87.359 \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Step-II : Mass of air [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho &=\frac{P}{R T}=\frac{100 \times 10^{3}}{289 \times 288} \\ &=1.2 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Mass of displaced volume of air [latex] =1.2 \times 523.33=628 \mathrm{kg}[/latex] Step-III : Net buoyant mass [latex] =628-87.359=540.64 \mathrm{kg}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Maximum allowable weight [latex] \begin{aligned} =540.64 \times 9.81 \\ =5303.688 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 122 The difference in pressure  (in [latex]N/m^{2}[/latex] ) across an air bubble of diameter 0.001 m immersed in water (surface tension = 0.072 N/m) is _______
solution: Forbuble, [latex]\quad \Delta P=\frac{2 \sigma}{r} [/latex] Where [latex] \Delta P [/latex]=pressure difference [latex] Surface tension : [latex]\sigma=0.072 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} [/latex] Radiu Ills of bubble: [latex] r=\frac{0.001}{2} \mathrm{m}=0.0005 \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \Delta P=\frac{2 \times 0.072}{0.0005}=288 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 123 For an incompressible flow field [latex]\vec{V}[/latex],  which one of the following conditions must be satisfied?
solution: For an incompressible flow field, divergence must be zero i.e., [latex] \nabla \cdot \vec{V}=0[/latex]

question: Question 124 An aluminium alloy (density 2600 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex] ) casting is to be produced. A cylindrical hole of 100 mm diameter and 100 mm length is made in the casting using sand core (density 1600 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex] ).  The net buoyancy force (in newton) acting on the core is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Volume of core } &=\frac{\pi}{4} D^{2} H=0.785 \times 0.1^{2} \times 0.1 \\ &=7.85 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \text{Net buoyancy force} &=\left(\rho_{\mathrm{A} 1}-\rho_{\text {core }}\right) V_{\text {core }} g \\ &=1000 \times 9.81 \times 7.85 \times 10^{-4} \\ &=7.7 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 125 In a simple concentric shaft-bearing arrangement, the lubricant flows in the 2 mm gap between the shaft and the bearing. The flow may be assumed to be a plane Couette flow with zero pressure gradient. The diameter of the shaft is 100 mm and its tangential speed is 10 m/s. The dynamic viscosity of the lubricant is 0.1 kg/m.s. The frictional resisting force (in newton) per 100 mm length of the bearing is  _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} d &=100 \mathrm{mm}=0.1 \mathrm{m} \\ L &=100 \mathrm{mm}=0.1 \mathrm{m} \\ u &=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \mu &=0.1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{ms} \\ d y &=2 \mathrm{mm}=2 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \\ \tau &=\mu \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{u}}{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{y}} \\ &=0.1 \times \frac{10}{2 \times 10^{-3}}=500 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \text{Frictional area }&= \pi dL=3.14 \times0.1 \times 0.1\\ &=0.0314 \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Frictional resistance force, [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\tau \times \pi \mathrm{d} L \\ &=500 \times 0.0314=15.7 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 126 For a fully developed flow of water in a pipe having diameter 10 cm, velocity 0.1 m/s and kinematic viscosity [latex]10^{-5}m^{2}/s[/latex] , the value of Darcy friction factor is _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} d&=10 \mathrm{cm} \\ V&=0.1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \mathrm{v}&=10^{-5} \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Reynold's number, [latex] \mathrm{Re}=\frac{V d}{v}=\frac{0.1 \times 0.1}{10^{-5}}=1000[/latex] Friction factor [latex] f=\frac{64}{\mathrm{Re}}=\frac{64}{1000}=0.064[/latex]

question: Question 127 Water flows through a pipe having an inner radius of 10 mm at the rate of 36 kg/hr at 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C.  The viscosity of water at 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C is 0.001 kg/m.s.  The Reynolds number of the flow is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Radius: }\quad r&=10 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \text{Diameter: }d&=2 r=2 \times 10=20 \mathrm{mm}=0.02 \mathrm{m} \\ m &=36 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{hr}=\frac{36}{3600}=0.01 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \\ \mu &=0.001 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{ms} \end{aligned}[/latex] Reynolds number: [latex]\text{Re}=\frac{\rho V d}{\mu}[/latex] From continuity equation, [latex]m=\rho A V [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{or }\quad V&=\frac{m}{\rho A}=\frac{m}{\frac{\rho \pi d^{2}}{4}}=\frac{4 m}{\rho \pi d^{2}} \\ \therefore \quad \mathrm{Re}&=\frac{\rho d}{\mu} \times \frac{4 \mathrm{m}}{\rho \pi d^{2}}=\frac{4 \mathrm{m}}{\pi \mu \mathrm{d}}\\ &=\frac{4 \times 0.01}{3.14 \times 0.001 \times 0.02}=636.94 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 128 An ideal water jet with volume flow rate of 0.05 [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex]  strikes a flat plate placed normal to its path and exerts a force of 1000 N. Considering the density of water as 1000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex], the diameter (in mm) of the water jet is  _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=0.05 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ F &=1000 \mathrm{N} \\ \rho &=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] F=\rho a V^{2} [/latex] where a= cross-section area fo the jet [latex] \begin{aligned} Q&=a V \\ \therefore \quad F&=\rho Q V \\ 1000 &=1000 \times 0.05 \times V \\ \text{or}\quad V &=20 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ Q &=a V \\ Q &=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} V \\ \text{or}\quad 0.05&=\frac{3.14}{4} \times d^{2} \times 20 \\ \text{or}\quad d^{2}&=0.00318 \\ d&=0.05643 \mathrm{m} \\&=56.43mm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 129 For a completely submerged body with centre of gravity 'G' and centre of buoyancy 'B', the condition of stability will be
solution: (A submerged body in stable equilibrium)

options.D: independent of the locations of G and B

question: Question 130 A hinged gate of length 5 m, inclined at 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] with the horizontal and with water mass on its left, is shown in the figure below. Density of water is 1000 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]. The minimum mass of the gate in kg per unit width (perpendicular to the plane of  paper), required to keep it closed is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} l &=5 \mathrm{m} \\ \theta &=30^{\circ} \\ \rho &=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ \hbar &=2.5 \sin 30^{\circ}=1.25 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} A &=b l=1 \times 5=5 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ I_{G} &=\frac{b l^{3}}{12}=\frac{1 \times(5)^{3}}{12}=10.41 \mathrm{m}^{4} \\ F &=\rho g A \bar{h}=1000 \times 9.81 \times 5 \times 1.25 \\ &=61312.5 \mathrm{N} \\ h^{*} &=\bar{h}+\frac{I_{\mathrm{G}}}{A \bar{h}} \sin ^{2} \theta \\ &=1.25+\frac{10.41}{5 \times 1.25} \sin ^{2} 30^{\circ} \\ &=1.666 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned} [/latex] Taking moment about hinge, Moment due F =Moment due to W [latex] F \times \frac{h^{\star}}{\sin 30^{\circ}}=W \times 2.5 \times \cos 30^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] 61312.5 \times \frac{1.666}{0.5}=\mathrm{Mg} \times 2.165 [/latex] [latex] or \quad M=9618.93 \mathrm{kg} \simeq 9623 \mathrm{kg}[/latex]

question: Question 131 Water is coming out from a tap and falls vertically downwards. At the tap opening, the stream diameter is 20 mm with uniform velocity of 2 m/s. Acceleration due to gravity is 9.81 m/[latex]s^2[/latex]. Assuming steady, inviscid flow, constant atmospheric pressure everywhere and neglecting curvature and surface tension effects, the diameter in mm of the stream 0.5 m below the tap is approximately
solution: Given data: At section 1-1 Diameter: [latex]\quad d_{1}=20 \mathrm{mm}=0.02 \mathrm{m} [/latex] Velocity: [latex] \quad V_{1}=2 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] Acceleration due to gravity, [latex] g=9.81 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}[/latex] Applying Bernoulli's equation between sections 1 and 2 , we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{p_{1}}{p g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1} &=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{2} \\ 0+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{\rho g}+0.5 &=0+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{\rho g}+0 \\ \frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+0.5 &=\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}\\ \text{ or }\qquad V_{2}^{2}&=V_{1}^{2}+0.5 \times 2 g\\ \text{or }\qquad V_{2} &=\sqrt{V_{1}^{2}+0.5 \times 2 \times g} \\ &=\sqrt{(2)^{2}+0.5 \times 2 \times 9.81} \\ &=\sqrt{13.81}=3.716 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying continuity equation between sections and 2, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{1} V_{1} &=A_{2} V_{2} \\ \frac{\pi}{4} d_{1}^{2} V_{1} &=\frac{\pi}{4} d_{2}^{2} V_{2}\\ \text{or }\quad d_{1}^{2} V_{1}&=d_{2}^{2} V_{2} \\ (0.02)^{2} \times 2&=d_{2}^{2} \times 3.716\\ \text{or }\quad d_{2}^{2}&=2.1528 \times 10^{-4}\\ \text{or }\quad d_{2} &=0.01467 \mathrm{m} \\ &=14.67 \mathrm{mm} \approx 15 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 132 In order to have maximum power from a Pelton turbine, the bucket speed must be
solution: Condition for maximum power form a Pelton turbine Bucket speed = Half of the jet speed [latex] u=\frac{V_{i}}{2}[/latex]

options.B: equal to half of the jet speed.
options.C: equal to twice the jet speed.

question:
Question 133 For steady, fully developed flow inside a straight pipe of diameter D, neglecting gravity effects, the pressure drop [latex]\Delta p[/latex]
 over a length L and the wall shear stress [latex]\tau _{w}[/latex]
 are reated by
solution: Shear stress on wall, [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau_{w} &=-\frac{\partial p}{\partial x} \frac{R}{2} \\ \text { where } \quad-\frac{\partial p}{\partial x} &=\frac{\Delta p}{L} \\ \Delta p &=\text { Pressure drop }\\ \text{and }\quad R&=\frac{D}{2}\\ \therefore \tau_{w}&=\frac{\Delta p}{L} \times \frac{D}{2 \times 2}=\frac{\Delta p D}{4 L} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 134 A large tank with a nozzle attached contains three immiscible, inviscid fluids as shown. Assuming that the changes in h1, h2 and h3 are negligible, the instantaneous discharge velocity is
solution: Total pressure at state 1 , [latex] P_{1}=\rho_{1} g h_{1}+\rho_{2} g h_{2}+\rho_{3} g h_{3} [/latex] Total pressure at state 2 [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{2} &=\frac{\rho_{3} V^{2}}{2} \\ \text { Thus, } P_{2} &=P_{1} \\ \frac{\rho^{3} V^{2}}{2} &=\rho_{1} g h_{1}+\rho_{2} g h_{2}+\rho_{3} g h_{3} \\ V^{2} &=2 g\left(\frac{\rho_{1}}{\rho_{3}} h_{1}+\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho_{3}} h_{2}+\frac{\rho_{1}}{\rho_{3}} h_{1}\right) \\ V &=\sqrt{2 g\left(h_{3}+\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho_{3}} h_{2}+\frac{\rho_{1}}{\rho_{3}} h_{1}\right)} \\ &=\sqrt{2 g h_{3}\left(1+\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho_{3}} \frac{h_{2}}{h_{3}}+\frac{\rho_{1}}{P_{3}} \frac{h_{1}}{h_{3}}\right)} \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternatively Applying the Bernoulli's equation between state 1 and 2, we get [latex] \frac{P_{1}}{\rho_{3} g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1}=\frac{P_{2}}{\rho_{3} g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{2}[/latex] where, [latex] \begin{aligned} z_{1} &=z_{2} \\ V_{1} &=0 \\ P_{2} &=0 \\ P_{1} &=\rho_{3} g h_{3}+\rho_{2} g h_{2}+\rho_{1} g h_{1} \\ \therefore \quad &\frac{\rho_{1} g h_{3}+\rho_{2} g h_{2}+\rho_{1} g h_{1} }{\rho_{3} g}+0+0 \\ &=0+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+0\\ h_{3}+\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho_{3}} h_{2}&+\frac{\rho_{1}}{\rho_{3}} h_{1}=\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}\\ or \quad V_{2}^{2}&=2 g\left(h_{3}+\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho_{3}} h_{2}+\frac{\rho_{1}}{\rho_{3}} h_{1}\right) \\ or \quad V_{2}&=\sqrt{2 g\left(h_{3}+\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho_{3}} h_{2}+\frac{\rho_{1}}{\rho_{3}} h_{1}\right)} \\ V_{2}&=\sqrt{2 g h_{3}\left(1+\frac{\rho_{2}}{\rho_{3}} \frac{h_{2}}{h_{3}}+\frac{\rho_{1}}{\rho_{3}} \frac{h_{1}}{h_{3}}\right)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 135 An incompressible fluid flows over a flat plate with zero pressure gradient. The boundary layer thickness is 1mm at a location where the Reynolds number is 1000. If the velocity of the fluid alone is increased by a factor of 4, then boundary layer thickness at the same location, in mm will be
solution: Boundary layer thickness, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta &\propto \frac{1}{\text{Re}_{x}^{1 / 2}} \text{ for laminar flow}\\ \text{and }\quad \operatorname{Re}_{x}&=\frac{V x}{v} \\ \text{i.e., }\quad \operatorname{Re}_{x} &\propto V \\ \therefore \quad \delta &\propto \frac{1}{V^{1 / 2}} \\ \delta_{1} V_{1}^{1 / 2} &=\delta_{2} V_{2}^{1 / 2} \\ 1 V^{1 / 2} &=\delta_{2}(4 V)^{1 / 2} \\ V^{1 / 2} &=\delta_{2} \times 2 V^{12} \\ \text{or }\quad \delta_{2}&=\frac{1}{2}=0.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ \end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 136 The velocity triangles at the inlet and exit of the rotor of a turbomachine are shown. V denotes the absolute velocity of the fluid. W denotes the relative velocity of the fluid and U denotes the blade velocity. Subscripts 1 and 2 refer to inlet and outlet respectively. If [latex]V_{2}=W_{1}[/latex]
 and [latex]V_{1}=W_{2}[/latex], then the degree of reaction is
solution: Degree of reaction [latex] R=1-\frac{(V_1^2-V_2^2)}{(V_1^2-V_2^2)+(U_1^2-U_2^2)+(W_2^2-W_1^2)}[/latex] [latex]\text{Where,}[/latex] [latex]V_1 \text{ and }V_2 \text{ are absolute velocities} [/latex] [latex]W_1 \text{ and }W_2 \text{ are relative velocities}[/latex] [latex]U_1 \text{ and }U_2=U \text{ for given figure} [/latex] [latex]\text{Given } W_2=V_1, W_1=V_2[/latex] [latex]\text{Hence,} [/latex] [latex]R=1-\frac{(V_1^2-V_2^2)}{(V_1^2-V_2^2)+(U^2-U^2)+(V_1^2-V_2^2)}[/latex] [latex]R =1-\frac{(V_1^2-V_2^2)}{2(V_1^2-V_2^2)} [/latex] [latex]R= 1-\frac{1}{2}[/latex] [latex] R = 0.5 [/latex]

question: Question 137 Oil flows through a 200 mm diameter horizontal cast iron pipe  (friction factor, f = 0.0225) of length 500 m. The volumetric flow rate is 0.2 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/s . The head loss (in m) due to friction is (assume g = 9.81 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex])
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} d=200 \mathrm{mm}&=0.2 \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore \qquad A=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2}&=\frac{3.14}{4} \times(0.2)^{2}\\ &=0.0314 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ f &=0.0225 \\ L &=500 \mathrm{m} \\ Q &=0.2 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ also \qquad Q &=A V\\ \therefore \qquad 0.2&=0.0314 \times V\\ or \qquad V&=6.369 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] We know that the Darcy's formula, head loss due to friction, [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{f} &=\frac{f L V^{2}}{2 g d} \\ &=\frac{0.0225 \times 500 \times(6.369)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.2} \\ &=116.29 \mathrm{m} \text { of oil } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 138 A pump handling a liquid raises its pressure from 1 bar to 30 bar. Take the density of the liquid as 990 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]. The isentropic specific work done by the pump in kJ/kg is
solution: Given data: Pressure of liquid at pump inlet, [latex] p_{1}=1 \mathrm{bar}=100 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Pressure of liquid at pump, [latex] p_{2}=30 \mathrm{bar}=3000 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Density of liquid, [latex] \rho=990 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Specific pump input work, [latex] \begin{aligned} w_{p} &=v\left(p_{2}-p_{1}\right) \\ &=\frac{\left(p_{2}-p_{1}\right)}{\rho} \quad \because v=1 / p \\ &=\frac{3000-100}{990}=2.929 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ &=2.93 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 139 Figure shows the schematic for the measurement of velocity of air (density = 1.2kg /[latex]m^{3}[/latex]) through a constant-area duct using a pitot tube and a water-tube manometer. The differential head of water (density = 1000 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] ) in the two columns of the manometer is 10mm. Take acceleration due to gravity as 9.8m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]. The velocity of air in m/s is
solution: Given data: Density of air, [latex] \rho_{a}=1.2 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Density of water, [latex] \rho_{w}=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Differential head in manometer [latex] \begin{aligned} h &=10 \mathrm{mm} \text { of water } \\ &=0.10 \mathrm{m} \text { of water } \end{aligned}[/latex] This reading is the dynamic pressure head. Hence dynamic pressure, [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{\text {dyn }} &=(\rho g h)_{\text {water }}=\rho_{w} g h \\ &=1000 \times 9.81 \times 0.01=98.1 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \text { also } p_{\text {dyn }} &=\left(\frac{1}{2} \rho V^{2}\right)_{\text {air }}=\frac{1}{2} \rho_{\mathrm{a}} V^{2}\\ 98.1 &=\frac{1}{2} \times 1.2 \times V^{2} \\ \text{or }\qquad V^{2} &=163.5\\ V&=12.78 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternatively [latex] V=\sqrt{2 g h} [/latex] [latex] h=x\left(\frac{\rho_{m}}{\rho}-1\right) [/latex] [latex] x= [/latex]reading of differential manometer [latex] =10 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] \rho_{m}= [/latex] density of manometric fluid =1000 [latex]\mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] [latex] \rho= [/latex] density of following fluid [latex] =1.2 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] [latex] V=\sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 10 \times 10^{-3}\left(\frac{1000}{1.2}-1\right)} [/latex] [latex] V=12.779 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \approx 12.8 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} [/latex]

question: Question 140 A streamline and an equipotential line in a flow field
solution: Stream line and equipotential line in a flow field are perpendicular to each other

question: Question 141 Match the following

Question 142 A smooth pipe of diameter 200mm carries water. The pressure in the pipe at section S1 (elevation: 10m) is 50kPa. At Section S2 (elevation: 12m) the pressure is 20kPa and velocity is [latex]2ms^{-1}[/latex]. Density of water is [latex]1000kgm^{-3}[/latex]
 and acceleration due to gravity is [latex]9.8ms^{-2}[/latex]. Which of the following is TRUE?
solution: Given data: At section S 1 [latex] \begin{aligned} d_{1}&=200 \mathrm{mm}=0.2 \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore \qquad A_{1}&=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2}=\frac{3.14}{4} \times(0.2)^{2} &=0.0314 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ z_{1} &=10 \mathrm{m} \\ p_{1} &=50 \mathrm{kPa} \\ V_{1} &=V_{2} \\ \rho &=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ and \qquad \mathrm{g} &=9.81 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\\ \text{At section S 2}\\ d_{2}&=d_{1} \\ \therefore A_{2}&=A_{1}\\ z_{2}&=12 \mathrm{m} \\ p_{2}&=20 \mathrm{kPa}=20 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{Pa} \\ V_{2}&=2 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Net head at section S 1: [latex] \begin{aligned} H_{1} &=\frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1} \\ &=\frac{50 \times 10^{3}}{1000 \times 9.1}+\frac{(2)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81}+10 \\ &=5.09+0.20+10=15.29 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Net head at section S 2: [latex] \begin{aligned} H_{2} &=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1} \\ &=\frac{20 \times 10^{3}}{1000 \times 9.1}+\frac{(2)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81}+12 \\ &=2.03+0.20+12=14.23 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] since net heat at section S1 is greater than at section S2, so the flow direction is from section S1 to section S2. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Head loss: } h_{f} &=H_{1}-H_{2} \\ &=15.29-14.23=1.06 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: flow from S1 to S2 and head loss is 0.53m
options.B: flow from S2 to S1 and head loss is 0.53m
options.C: flow from S1 to S2 and head loss is 1.06m
options.D: flow from S2 to S1 and head loss is 1.06m

question:
Question 143 Velocity vector of a flow field is given as [latex]\vec{V}= 2xy\hat{i}-x^{2}z\hat{j}[/latex]
. The vorticity vector at [latex](1,1,1)[/latex]
 is
solution: vorticity vector, [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}i & j & k \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ 2 x y & -x^{2} z & 0\end{array}\right| \\ &=\hat{i}\left[0-\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\left(-x^{2} z\right)\right]-\hat{j}\left[0-\frac{\partial}{\partial z}(2 x y)\right] \\ &+\hat{k}\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(-x^{2} z\right)-\frac{\partial}{\partial y}(2 x y)\right] \\ &=\hat{i}\left(x^{2}\right)+\hat{k}(-2 x z-2 x)-0 \\ &=i\left(x^{2}\right)+\hat{k}(-2 x z-2 x)-0 \\ &\therefore \operatorname{At}(1,1,1) \end{aligned}[/latex] vorticity vector [latex]=\hat{i}-4 \hat{k} [/latex]

question: Question 144 A hydraulic turbine develops 1000kW power for a head of 40m. If the head is reduced to 20m, the power developed (in kW) is
solution: Condition-1 [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{1}&=1000 \mathrm{kW} \\ H_{1}&=40 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Condition-2 [latex] P_{2}=?[/latex] [latex] H_{2}=20 \mathrm{m}[/latex] We know that the unit power, [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{u} &=\frac{P}{H^{3 / 2}} \\ \left(P_{U}\right)_{1} &=\left(P_{u}\right)_{2} \\ \frac{P_{1}}{H_{1}^{3 / 2}} &=\frac{P_{2}}{H_{2}^{3 / 2}} \\ \frac{1000}{(40)^{3 / 2}} &=\frac{P_{2}}{(20)^{3 / 2}} \\ \text{or}\quad P_{2} &=1000 \times \frac{(20)^{3 / 2}}{(40)^{3 / 2}}\\ &=\frac{1000}{(2)^{3 / 2}}=\frac{1000}{2^{1.5}}=353.55 \mathrm{kW} \\ &=354 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 145 A phenomenon is modeled using n dimensional variables with k primary dimensions. The number of non-dimensional variables is
solution: From Buckingham's [latex]\pi[/latex]-theorem It states "If there are n variable (Independent & dependent variables) in a physical phenomenon & if these variables contain m fundamental dimensions (M,L,T),  then variables are arranged into (n-m) dimensionless terms. Here n = dimensional variables k = Primary dimensions (M, L, T) So, non dimensional variables is n-k.

question: Question 146 The maximum velocity of a one-dimensional incompressible fully developed viscous flow, between two fixed parallel plates, is 6[latex]ms^{-1}[/latex]. The mean velocity (in [latex]ms^{-1}[/latex]) of the flow is
solution: [latex]U_{\max }=6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] Ratio of maximum velocity to average velocity for one dimensional incompressible flow between two fixed plate is [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{U_{\max }}{\bar{u}} &=\frac{3}{2} \\ \text{or}\quad \bar{u} &=\frac{6 \times 2}{3}=4 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 147 For the stability of a floating body, under the influence of gravity alone, which of the following is TRUE?
solution: As shown in figure above. If point B' is sufficiently far from B, these two forces (Gravity force and Buoyant force) create a restoring moment and return the body to the original position. A measure of stability for floating bodies is the metacentric height GM , which is the distance between the centre of gravity G and the metacenter M (the intersection point of the lines of action of the buoyant force through the body before and after rotation.) A floating body is stable if point M is above the point G, and thus GM is positive, and unstable if point M is below point G, and thus GM is negative. Stable equilibrium occurs when M is above G.

options.A: Metacentre should be below centre of gravity
options.B: Metacentre should be above centre of gravity
options.C: Metacentre and centre of gravity must lie on the same horizontal line
options.D: Metacentre and centre of gravity must lie on the same vertical line

question:
Question 148 The velocity profile of a fully developed laminar flow in a straight circular pipe, as shown in the figure, is given by the expression [latex]u(r)= -\frac{R^{2}}{4\mu }\left ( \frac{dp}{dx} \right )\left ( 1-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}} \right )[/latex]

 where 
[latex]\frac{dp}{dx}[/latex]

 is a constant. The average velocity of fluid in the pipe is
solution: The velocity profile of a fully developed laminar flow in a straight circular pipe, as shown in figure,  is given by the expression [latex] \begin{aligned} u(r) &=-\frac{R^{2}}{4 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left[1-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}\right] \\ &=U_{\max }\left[1-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}\right] \\ \text { where } \quad U_{\max } &=-\frac{R^{2}}{4 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] where [latex]\frac{d p}{d x}[/latex] is a constant The average velocity of fluid in the pipe, [latex] V_{\mathrm{avg}}=\frac{U_{\max }}{2}=-\frac{R^{2}}{8 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)[/latex] Alternatively Given velocity profile expression, [latex] u(r)=\frac{-R^{2}}{4 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left[1-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}\right][/latex] Consider a small circular ring element of radius r and thickness dr as shown in figure. The fluld flowing por socond through small elementaryring. dQ= Velocity at radius r x Area of a small ring element of a small [latex] \begin{aligned} &=u \times 2 \pi r d r \\ &=\frac{-1}{4 \mu} R^{2}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left[1-\frac{r^{2}}{R^{2}}\right] \times 2 \pi r d r \\ &=\frac{-\pi}{2 \mu} R^{2}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left[r-\frac{r^{3}}{R^{2}}\right] d r \end{aligned}[/latex] Net discharge flow through pipe, [latex] \begin{aligned} Q &=\int_{0}^{R} \frac{-\pi}{2 \mu} R^{2}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left[r-\frac{r^{3}}{R^{2}}\right] d r \\ &=\frac{-\pi}{2 \mu} R^{2}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right) \int_{0}^{R}\left[r-\frac{r^{3}}{R^{2}}\right] d r \\ &=\frac{-\pi}{2 \mu} R^{2}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left[\frac{r^{2}}{2}-\frac{r^{4}}{4 R^{2}}\right]^{A} \\ &=\frac{-\pi}{2 \mu} R^{2}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left[\frac{R^{2}}{2}-\frac{R^{4}}{4 R^{2}}\right] \\ &=\frac{-\pi}{2 \mu} R^{2}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\left(\frac{R^{2}}{2}-\frac{R^{4}}{4}\right) \\ &=\frac{-\pi}{2 \mu} R^{2}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right) \times \frac{R^{2}}{4}=\frac{-\pi}{8 \mu} R^{4}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)\end{aligned}[/latex] Average velocity, [latex] \begin{aligned}\bar{u} &=\frac{Q}{\pi R^{2}}=\frac{\overline{8} \mu}{\pi R^{2}}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right) \\ &=\frac{- R^{2}}{8 \mu}\left(\frac{d p}{d x}\right)  \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 149 Water at 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C is flowing through a 1.0km long G.I pipe of 200mm diameter at the rate of [latex]0.07m^{3}/s[/latex]
. If value of Darcy friction factor for this pipe is 0.02 and density of water is [latex]1000kg/m^{3}[/latex]
, the pumping power (in kW) required to maintain the flow is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Length: }\quad L&=1 \mathrm{km}=1000 \mathrm{m} \\ \text{Diameter: }\quad d&=200 \mathrm{mm}=0.2 \mathrm{m}\\ \text{Discharge: }\quad Q&=0.07 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \\ \text{Friction factor}\\ f&=0.02 \\ \text { Density: } \rho&=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ Q&=A V \\ Q&=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} V \\ 0.07&=\frac{3.14}{4} \times(0.2)^{2} \times V\\ or \qquad V&=2.23 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] We know that head loss due to function, [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{f} &=\frac{f L V^{2}}{2 g d}=\frac{0.02 \times 1000 \times(2.23)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.2} \\ &=25.34 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Pumping power required to maintain the flow, [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=\rho Q g h_{f} \\ &=1000 \times 0.07 \times 9.81 \times 25.34 \\ &=17400.9 \mathrm{W}=17.4 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 150 You are asked to evaluate assorted fluid flows for their suitability in a given laboratory application. The following three flow choices, expressed in terms of the two-dimensional velocity fields in the xy-plane, are made available. P. [latex]u=2y, v=-3x[/latex] Q. [latex]u=3xy, v=0[/latex] R.[latex]u=-2x, v=2y[/latex] Which flow(s) should be recommended when the application requires the flow to be incompressible and irrotational?
solution:
Incompressible flow satisfy continuity equation [latex]  rac{\partial u}{\partial x}+ rac{\partial v}{\partial y}=0 [/latex] [latex] P. u=2 y, v=-3 x [/latex] [latex]  rac{\partial(2 y)}{\partial x}+ rac{\partial(-3 x)}{\partial y} [/latex] Incompressible flow [latex] \Rightarrow \quad 0+0=0 [/latex] [latex] Q. u=3 x y, v=0 [/latex] [latex]  rac{\partial(3 x y)}{\partial x}+ rac{\partial(0)}{\partial y} [/latex] Compressible flow [latex] \Rightarrow 3 y+0 
eq 0 [/latex] [latex] R. u=-2 x, v=2 y [/latex] [latex]  rac{\partial(-2 x)}{\partial x}+ rac{\partial(2 y)}{\partial y} [/latex] Incompressible flow [latex] -2+2=0[/latex] For irrotational flow condition is [latex]  egin{aligned} \omega_{2} &= rac{1}{2}\left( rac{\partial v}{\partial x}- rac{\partial u}{\partial y}ight)=0 \ 	ext { For P:} \quad & u=2 y, v=-3 x \ & \omega_{2}= rac{1}{2}\left[ rac{\partial(-3 x)}{\partial x}- rac{\partial(2 y)}{\partial y}ight] \ &= rac{1}{2}[-3-2] 
eq 0 \;\;\;	ext{   (Rotational flow)}\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] egin{aligned} 	ext{For Q: }\quad u &=3 x y, v=0 \ \omega_{2} &= rac{1}{2}\left[ rac{\partial(0)}{\partial x}- rac{\partial(3 x y)}{\partial y}ight] \ &= rac{1}{2}[0-3 x] 
eq 0 \;\;\;	ext{   (Rotational flow)} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] egin{aligned} 	ext{For R: }\quad u &=-2 x, v=2 y \ \omega_{2} &= rac{1}{2}\left[ rac{\partial(2 y)}{\partial x}- rac{\partial(-2 x)}{\partial y}ight] \ &= rac{1}{2}[0-0]=0 \; \; \; 	ext{  (Irrotational flow)}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 151 Consider steady, incompressible and irrotational flow through a reducer in a horizontal pipe where the diameter is reduced from 20cm to 10cm. The pressure in the 20cm pipe just upstream of the reducer is 150kPa. The fluid has a vapour pressure of 50kPa and a specific weight of [latex]5 kN/m^{3}[/latex]. Neglecting frictional effects, the maximum discharge (in [latex]m^{3}/s[/latex]) that can pass through the reducer without causing cavitation is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} d_{1}&=20 \mathrm{cm}=0.2 \mathrm{m} \\ d_{2}&=10 \mathrm{cm}=0.1 \mathrm{mm} \\ p_{1}&=150 \mathrm{kP} \mathrm{a}=150000 \mathrm{Pa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Vapour pressure, [latex] p_{v}=50 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] Specific weight [latex] w=5 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{3}=5000 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{3}=\rho \mathrm{g} [/latex] Applying continuity equation at section (1)-(1) and (2)-(2), we get [latex] A_{1} V_{1}=A_{2} V_{2} \quad [/latex] for incompressible flow [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\pi}{4} d_{1}^{2} V_{1} &=\frac{\pi}{4} d_{2}^{2} V_{2} \\ d_{1}^{2} V_{1} &=d_{2}^{2} V_{2}\\ or \quad V_{1}&=\left(\frac{d_{2}}{d_{1}}\right)^{2} V_{2}=\left(\frac{10}{20}\right)^{2} V_{2} \\ V_{1}&=0.25 \mathrm{V}_{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] The maximum pressure in downstream of reducer should be greater or equal to vapour pressure [latex]\left(p_{v}\right)[/latex] to avoid cavitation. Therefore for maximum discharge, [latex]p_{2}=p_{v}=50 \mathrm{kPa}=50000 \mathrm{Pa}[/latex] Applying Bernoulli's equation a section (1)-(1) and (2)-(2), we get [latex] \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1}=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{2} [/latex] [latex] \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g} \quad \because z_{1}=z_{2} [/latex] [latex] \frac{150000}{5000}+\frac{(0.25)^{2} V_{2}^{2}}{2 \times 9.81}=\frac{50000}{5000}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 \times 9.81} [/latex] [latex] 30+0.00318 V_{2}^{2}=10+0.0509 V_{2}^{2} [/latex] [latex] V_{2}^{2}=418.51 [/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad V_{2}=20.45 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad Q=A_{2} V_{2}=\frac{\pi}{4} d_{2}^{2} V_{2} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{3.14}{4} \times(0.1)^{2} \times 20.45=0.160 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question: Question 152 The gap between a moving circular plate and a stationary surface is being continuously reduced, as the circular plate comes down at a uniform speed V towards the stationary bottom surface, as shown in the figure. In the process, the fluid contained between the two plates flows out radially. The fluid is assumed to be incompressible and inviscid. The radial component of the fluid acceleration at r = R is
solution: Radial acceleration, [latex] \begin{aligned} a_{r}=V_{r} \times \frac{\partial V_{r}}{\partial r}+\frac{\partial V_{r}}{\partial t} \\ a_{r}=\frac{V r}{2 h} \times \frac{\partial}{\partial r}\left(\frac{V r}{2 h}\right)+\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\frac{V r}{\partial t}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] For convective part r is variable and for local acceleration h is variable [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad a_{r}&=\frac{V r}{2 h} \times \frac{V}{2 h} \times \frac{V}{2 h}+\frac{V r}{2} \times\left(\frac{-1}{h^{2}} \frac{\partial h}{\partial t}\right) \\ \frac{-\partial h}{\partial t}&=V\\ \therefore \quad a_{r}&=\frac{V^{2} r}{4 h^{2}}+\frac{V r}{2} \times\left(\frac{V}{h^{2}}\right)\\ a_{1}&=\frac{3 V^{2} r}{4 h^{2}}\\ \text{at }\quad r&=R \\ a_{R}&=\frac{3 V^{2} R}{4 h^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 153 The gap between a moving circular plate and a stationary surface is being continuously reduced, as the circular plate comes down at a uniform speed V towards the stationary bottom surface, as shown in the figure. In the process, the fluid contained between the two plates flows out radially. The fluid is assumed to be incompressible and inviscid. The radial velocity [latex]v_r[/latex] at any radius r, when the gap width is h, is
solution: Let us consider for small time d t, then for any  cylindrical control volume between 2 plates of radius r volume reduced by the movement of upper plate in time d t is equal to the volume of fluid moving out [latex] \therefore \qquad V \times \pi r^{2}=V_{r} \times 2 \pi r h[/latex] [latex] or \qquad V_{r}=\frac{V r}{2 h}[/latex]

question:
Question 154 Water, having a density of 1000 kg/[latex]m^3[/latex], issues from a nozzle with a velocity of 10 m/s and the jet
strikes a bucket mounted on a Pelton wheel. The wheel rotates at 10 rad/s. The mean diameter of
the wheel is 1 m. The jet is split into two equal streams by the bucket, such that each stream is
deflected by 120[latex]^{\circ}[/latex], as shown in the figure. Friction in the bucket may be neglected. Magnitude of the
torque exerted by the water on the wheel, per unit mass flow rate of the incoming jet, is
solution:
Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho&=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ V_{i}&=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \omega&=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ D&=1 \mathrm{m} \\ u&=\omega R=\frac{\omega D}{2}=10 \times \frac{1}{2}=5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Angle of deflection [latex]=120^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \beta_{0}=180^{\circ}-120^{\circ}=60^{\circ}[/latex] Force exerted by the water of the wheel per mass flow rate, [latex] \begin{aligned} F &=\left(V_{i}-u\right)\left(1+\cos \beta_{0}\right) N /(\mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s}) \\ &=(10-5)\left(1+\cos 60^{\circ}\right) \\ &=7.5 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Torque exerted by the water on the wheel per unit 
 mass flow rate, [latex] \begin{aligned} T &=F \frac{D}{2}=7.5 \times \frac{1}{2} \\ &=3.75 \mathrm{Nm} /(\mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s}) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 155 For a continuity equation given by  [latex]\vec{\triangledown} \cdot \vec{V}=0[/latex] to be valid, where  [latex]\vec{V}[/latex] is the velocity vector, which one of
the following is a necessary condition?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{\nabla} \cdot \vec{v}&=0\\ \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial v}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial w}{\partial z} &=0 \\ \rho\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial v}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial w}{\partial z}\right) &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] So, the above equation represents incompressible flow.

question:
Question 156 Consider a steady incompressible flow through a channel as shown below. The velocity profile is uniform with a value of [latex]u_0[/latex] at the inlet section A. The velocity profile at section B downstream is [latex]u=\left\{\begin{matrix} V_m\frac{y}{\delta }, & 0\leq y\leq \delta \\ V_m,& \delta \leq y\leq H-\delta \\ V_m\frac{H-y}{\delta }, & H-\delta \leq y\leq H \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] The ratio [latex]\frac{P_{A}-P_{B}}{\frac{1}{2}\rho u_{0}^{2}}[/latex]
 (where  and [latex]P_{A}[/latex]
 are [latex]P_{B}[/latex]
 the pressures at section A and B, respectively, and [latex]\rho[/latex]
 is the density of the fluid) is
solution: Applying Bernoulli's equation at sections A and B,we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{p_{A}}{p_{g}}+\frac{u_{0}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{A}&=\frac{p_{A}}{p g}+\frac{V_{m}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{B} \\ \frac{p_{A}}{\rho g}+\frac{u_{0}^{2}}{2 g}&=\frac{p_{B}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{m}^{2}}{2 g} \quad \because z_{A}=z_{B}\\ \text{or }\quad \frac{p_{A}}{\rho g}-\frac{p_{B}}{\rho g}&=\frac{V_{m}^{2}}{2 g}-\frac{u_{0}^{2}}{2 g} \\ \text{or }\quad p_{A}-p_{B}&=\frac{\rho V_{m}^{2}}{2}-\frac{\rho u_{0}^{2}}{2} \\ \text{Now, the ratio}\\ \frac{p_{A}-p_{B}}{\frac{1}{2} \rho u_{0}^{2}} &=\frac{\frac{\rho V_{m}^{2}}{2}-\frac{\rho u_{0}^{2}}{2}}{\frac{1}{2} \rho u_{0}^{2}} \\ &=\frac{V_{m}^{2}-u_{0}^{2}}{u_{0}^{2}}=\left(\frac{V_{m}}{u_{0}}\right)^{2}-1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Substituting the value of [latex]\frac{V_{m}}{u_{0}}=\frac{1}{1-(\delta / H)} [/latex] [latex] \frac{p_{A}-p_{B}}{\frac{1}{2} \rho u_{0}^{2}}=\frac{1}{[1-(\delta / H)]^{2}}-1[/latex]

question:
Question 157 Consider a steady incompressible flow through a channel as shown below. The velocity profile is uniform with a value of [latex]u_0[/latex] at the inlet section A. The velocity profile at section B downstream is [latex]u=\left\{\begin{matrix} V_m\frac{y}{\delta }, & 0\leq y\leq \delta \\ V_m,& \delta \leq y\leq H-\delta \\ V_m\frac{H-y}{\delta }, & H-\delta \leq y\leq H \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] The ratio [latex]V_{m}/u_{0}[/latex]
 is
solution: Applying continuiting equation at sections A and B, mass flow rate at inlet section A = Mass rate at section B. [latex]m_A=m_B[/latex] Hence, per unit width of the channel, we get [latex]\begin{aligned} \rho u_0 H \times 1 &=\rho V_m(H-2\delta )\times 1+2\rho \int_{0}^{\delta }udy \times 1 \\ u_0 H &=V_m(H-2\delta )+2 \int_{0}^{\delta }\frac{V_my}{\delta }dy \\ u_0 H &=V_m(H-2\delta )+2 \frac{V_m}{\delta } \left [ \frac{y^2}{2} \right ]_0 ^\delta \\ u_0 H &= V_m(H-2\delta )+2 \frac{V_m}{\delta } \times \frac{\delta ^2}{2}\\ u_0 H &= V_m(H-2\delta )+ V_m\delta \\ u_0 H&= V_mH-2V_m\delta +V_m\delta \\ u_0 H&= V_mH-V_m\delta \\ u_0 H &=V_m(H-\delta ) \\ \frac{V_m}{u_0}&=\frac{H}{H-\delta }=\frac{1}{1-(\delta /H)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 158 Match the items in columns I and II.
solution: (P) Centrifugal compressor -  Surging (Q) Centrifugal pump -  Priming (R) Pelton wheel- Pure impulse (Q) Kaplan turbine -  Axial flow

question:
Question 159 Which combination of the following statements about steady incompressible forced vortex flow is
correct? P: Shear stress is zero at all points in the flow. Q: Vorticity is zero at all points in the flow. R: Velocity is directly proportional to the radius from the centre of the vortex. S: Total mechanical energy per unit mass is constant in the entire flow field.
solution:
For forced Vortex flow the relation is given by, [latex]V=r\omega[/latex] From above equation,  it is shown easily that velocity is directly proportional to the
radius from the centre of the vortex (Radius of fluid particle from the axis of
rotation) And also for forced vortex flow, [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} \rho \omega ^2(r_2^2-r_1^2)-\rho g(z_2-z_1)&=0 \\ \Delta K.E. -\Delta P.E.&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \;\; \Delta K.E.&= \Delta P.E. \end{aligned}[/latex] Now total mechanical energy per unit mass is constant in the entire flow field.

question: Question 160 Which combination of the following statements is correct? P. A gas cools upon expansion only when its Joule-Thomson co-efficient is positive in the temperature range of expansion. Q. For a system undergoing a process, its entropy remains constant only when the process is reversible. R. The work done by a closed system in an adiabatic process is a point function. S. A liquid expands upon freezing when the slope of its fusion curve on Pressure-Temperature diagram is negative.
solution: For steady, incompressible forced, vortex flow; P. Shear stress in zero at all points in the flow. --Incorrect Shear stress is always exit dut to external torque acting on mass of fluid. Q.Vorticity is zero at all points in the flow.-- Incorrect Velocity exists at all points in forced vortex flow field. R. Velocity is directly proportional to the radius from the centre of the vortex. - Correct. For forced vortex flow, [latex] \frac{V}{r}=\text { Constant }[/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad V \propto r [/latex] S. Total mechanical energy per unit mass is constant in the entire flow field. - Correct [latex] \frac{\rho \omega^{2}}{2}\left(r_{2}^{2}-r_{1}^{2}\right)-\rho g\left(z_{2}-z_{1}\right)=0 [/latex] [latex] \text{or }\frac{\omega^{2}}{2}\left(r_{2}^{2}-r_{1}^{2}\right)-g\left(z_{2}-z_{1}\right)=0 [/latex] [latex] \Delta \mathrm{K} . \mathrm{E} .-\Delta \mathrm{P.E.}=0 [/latex] where, [latex] \Delta K . E .=\frac{\omega^{2}}{2}\left(r_{2}^{2}-r_{1}^{2}\right)-\left(z_{2}-z_{1}\right) [/latex] change in K.E. per unit mass [latex] \Delta P . E=g\left(z_{2}-z_{1}\right) \quad [/latex] change in P.E. per unit mass [latex] \therefore \Delta K \cdot E .=\Delta P . E [/latex] Hence, total mechanical energy per unit mass in constant.

question: Question 161 A model of a hydraulic turbine is tested at a head of 1/4th of that under which the full scale turbine works. The diameter of the model is half of that of the full scale turbine. If N is the RPM of the full scale turbine, then the RPM of the model will be
solution: Given data: Model [latex] \begin{aligned} H_{m}&=\frac{H_{p}}{4} ; \quad D_{m}=\frac{D_{p}}{2} \\ N_{m}&=? \end{aligned}[/latex] Prototype (full scale turbine) [latex] N_{p}=N[/latex] We know that head coefficient [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{H} &=\frac{H}{(N D)^{2}} \\ \left(C_{H}\right)_{\text{model}} &=\left(C_{H}\right)_{\text {prootipe }} \\ \frac{H_{m}}{N_{m}^{2} D_{m}^{2}} &=\frac{H_{p}}{N_{p}^{2} D_{p}^{2}} \\ \frac{H_{p} / 4}{N_{m}^{2} \times \frac{D_{p}^{2}}{4}} &=\frac{H_{p}}{N^{2} \times D_{p}^{2}} \\ \text{or}\quad N_{m}^{2} &=N^{2}\\ \text{or }\quad N_{m}&=N \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 162 The inlet angle of runner blades of a Francis turbine is 90[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. The blades are so shaped that the tangential component of velocity at blade outlet is zero. The flow velocity remains constant throughout the blade passage and is equal to half of the blade velocity at runner inlet. The blade efficiency of the runner is
solution: Given data: [latex]\begin{aligned} \beta_{i} &=90^{\circ} \\ V_{w 0} &=0 \\ V_{t_{i}} &=V_{t_{0}}=\frac{u_{i}}{2} \end{aligned} [/latex] Blade efficiency of the runner, [latex] \eta_{H}=\frac{V_{w i} u_{i}}{g H}=\frac{u_{i}^{2}}{g H} \quad \because V_{w i}=u_{i}[/latex] By energy balance equation, [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho Q g H &=\rho Q V_{w i} u_{i}+\frac{\rho Q V_{0}^{2}}{2} \\ g H &=u_{i}^{2}+\frac{V_{f 0}^{2}}{2}=u_{i}^{2}+\frac{u_{i}^{2}}{8} \\ g H &=\frac{9}{8} u_{i}^{2}\\ \therefore \quad \eta_{H} &=\frac{u_{i}^{2}}{\frac{9}{8} u_{i}^{2}}=\frac{8}{9}=0.8888 \\ &=88.88 \% \approx 89 \% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 163 Consider steady laminar incompressible axi-symmetric fully developed viscous flow through a straight circular pipe of constant cross - sectional area at a Reynolds number of 5. The ratio of inertia force to viscous force on a fluid particle is
solution: Reynolds number, [latex] \mathrm{Re}=\frac{\text { Inertia force }}{\text { viscous force }}=5[/latex]

question: Question 164 In a steady flow through a nozzle, the flow velocity on the nozzle axis is given by [latex]v = u_{0}\left ( 1+\frac{3x}{L} \right )i[/latex], where x  is the distance along the axis of the nozzle from its inlet plane and L is the length of the nozzle. The time required for a fluid particle on the axis to travel from the inlet to the exit lane of the nozzle is
solution: [latex]v=u_{o}\left(1+\frac{3 x}{L}\right) [/latex] We know that Velocity: [latex]\quad v=\frac{d x}{d t} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \frac{d x}{d t}=u_{0}\left(1+\frac{3 x}{L}\right) [/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad u_{0}. d t=\frac{d x}{\left(1+\frac{3 x}{L}\right)} [/latex] Integrating both sides, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} u_{0} \int_{0}^{t} d t &=\int_{0}^{L} \frac{d x}{\left(1+\frac{3 x}{L}\right)} \\ u_{0} t &=\frac{L}{3}\left[\ln \left(1+\frac{3 x}{L}\right)\right]_{0}^{L}=\frac{L}{3} \ln 4 \\ \therefore \quad t &=\frac{L}{3 u_{0}} \ln 4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 165 Consider an incompressible laminar boundary layer flow over a flat plate of length L, aligned with the direction of an oncoming uniform free stream. If F is the ratio of the drag force on the front half of the plate to the drag force on the rear half, then
solution: Drag force, [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{D} &=C_{f} \times \frac{1}{2} \rho A V^{2}=\frac{1.328}{\sqrt{\text{Re}_{L}}} \times \frac{1}{2} \rho A V^{2} \\ &=\frac{1.328}{\sqrt{\frac{\rho L V}{\mu}}} \times \frac{1}{2} \rho \times A \times L \times V^{2}\\ \text{i.e. }F_{D} &\propto \sqrt{L} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Now Drag force on front half, [latex] \begin{aligned} \quad F_{D R} &\propto \sqrt{\frac{L}{2}} \\ \therefore F_{D / 2}&=\frac{F_{D}}{\sqrt{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Drag force on rear half, [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{D / 2}^{\prime}&=F_{D}-F_{D / 2}=\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) F_{D}\\ \text{Now} F&=\frac{F_{D / 2}}{F_{D / 2}^{\prime}}=\frac{\frac{F_{D}}{\sqrt{2}}}{\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) F_{D}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}-1}>1\\ \therefore \quad F&>1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 166 A smooth flat plate with a sharp leading edge is placed along a gas stream flowing at U = 10 m/s. The thickness of the boundary layer at section r-s is 10 mm, the breadth of the plate is 1 m (into the paper) and the density of the gas [latex]\rho = 1.0 kg/m^{3}[/latex]. Assume that the boundary layer is thin, two-dimensional, and follows a linear velocity distribution, [latex]u= U(y/\delta )[/latex], the section r-s, where y is the height from plate. The integrated drag force (in N) on the plate, between p-s, is:
solution: Drag force on plate = rate of change of momentum of the flowing fluid. Momentum thickness: [latex] \theta=\int_{0}^{\delta} \frac{u}{U}\left(\frac{1-u}{U}\right) d y [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta &=\int_{0}^{\delta} \frac{U}{\delta}\left(1-\frac{u}{\delta}\right) d y=\int_{0}^{\delta}\left(\frac{y}{\delta}-\frac{y^{2}}{\delta^{2}}\right) d y \\ &=\frac{y^{2}}{2 \delta}-\left.\frac{y^{3}}{3 \delta^{2}}\right|_{0} ^{\delta}=\frac{\delta}{2}-\frac{\delta}{3}=\frac{\delta}{6} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Force on plate per unit width [latex]=\delta U^{2} \times(\theta \times 1) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Here, } \quad U &=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ &=1 \times(10)^{2} \times\left(\frac{10 \times 10^{-3}}{6} \times 1\right) \\ &=0.1666 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 167 A smooth flat plate with a sharp leading edge is placed along a gas stream flowing at U = 10 m/s. The thickness of the boundary layer at section r-s is 10 mm, the breadth of the plate is 1 m (into the paper) and the density of the gas [latex]\rho = 1.0 kg/m^{3}[/latex]. Assume that the boundary layer is thin, two-dimensional, and follows a linear velocity distribution, [latex]u= U(y/\delta )[/latex], the section r-s, where y is the height from plate. The mass flow rate (in kg/s) across the section q-r is:
solution: Velocity of free stream, [latex] U=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] Boundary layer thickness at section r-s, [latex] \delta=10 \mathrm{mm}=0.01 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Width of the plate: b=1m Density of the gas: [latex] p=1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} [/latex] Linear velocity distribution, [latex] u=U \frac{y}{\delta}[/latex] Mass flow rate entering through section p q [latex] \begin{aligned} \dot{m} &=\rho A U=\rho b \delta U \\ &=1 \times 1 \times 0.01 \times 10=0.1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Mass flow rate entering through section s-r [latex] \begin{aligned} \dot{m}&=\int_{0}^{\delta} \rho a u=\int_{0}^{\delta} \rho b d y u \\ &=\rho b\int_{0}^{\delta}u d y=\rho b \int_{0}^{\delta} \frac{u y}{\delta} d y\\ &\left(\because u=\frac{U y}{\delta}\right) \\=& \frac{\rho b U^{\delta}}{\delta} \int_{0}^{\delta} y d y=\frac{\rho b U}{\delta}\left[\frac{y^{2}}{2}\right]_{0}^{\delta} \\=& \frac{\rho b U}{\delta} \times \frac{\delta^{2}}{2}=\frac{\rho b U \delta}{2} \\=& \frac{1 \times 1 \times 10 \times 0.01}{2}=0.05 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 168 A horizontal shaft centrifugal pump lifts ware at 65[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The suction nozzle is one meter below pump centerline. The pressure at this point equal 200 kPa gauge and velocity is 3 m/s. Steam tables show saturation pressure at 65[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C is 25 kPa, and specific volume of the saturated liquid is 0.001020 [latex]m^{3}/kg[/latex]. The pump Net Positive suction Head (NPSH) in meters is:
solution: Given data: Temperature of water [latex] T=65^{\circ} \mathrm{C}[/latex] Section head, [latex] h_{s}=1 \mathrm{m}[/latex] Gange pressure at section nozzle inlet,[/latex] [latex] p_{1, g}=200 \mathrm{kPa}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Absolute pressure [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1, \mathrm{abs}} &=p_{1, g}+p_{a t m} \\ &=200+101.325 \\ &=301.325 \mathrm{kPa} \\ &=301.325 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{Pa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Velocity at section nozzle inlet, [latex] V_{1}=3 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] Saturated pressure at [latex]65^{\circ} \mathrm{C} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{v, a b s} &=25 \mathrm{kPa}, \text { vapure pressure } \\ &=25 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{Pa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Specific volume, [latex] v=0.001020 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \text{Density: }\rho=\frac{1}{0.001020}=980.39 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}[/latex] Net positive section head, [latex] \mathrm{NPSH}=\frac{p_{s, a b s}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{s}^{2}}{2 g}-\frac{p_{v, a b s}}{\rho g}[/latex] Applying Bernoullis equation at section nozzle inlet and section of the pump [latex] \frac{p_{1, a b s}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1}=\frac{p_{s, a b s}}{p g}+\frac{v_{s}^{2}}{2 g}+h_{s}[/latex] [latex]\frac{\mathrm{p}_{1, \mathrm{abs}}}{\mathrm{pg}}+\frac{\mathrm{V}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{g}}+0=\frac{\mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{s}, \mathrm{abs}}}{\mathrm{pg}}+\frac{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{s}}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{g}}+\mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{s}} [/latex] [latex] or \frac{\mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{s}, \mathrm{abs}}}{\mathrm{pg}}+\frac{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{s}}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{g}}=\frac{\mathrm{p}_{1 \mathrm{abs}}}{\mathrm{pg}}+\frac{\mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{g}}-\mathrm{h}_{\mathrm{s}} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \mathrm{NPSH}=\frac{\mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{s}, \mathrm{abs}}}{\mathrm{pg}}+\frac{\mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}}{2 \mathrm{g}}-h_{\mathrm{s}}-\frac{\mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{v}, \mathrm{abs}}}{\mathrm{pg}} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{301 \cdot 325 \times 10^{3}}{980.39 \times 9.81}+\frac{(3)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81}-1-\frac{25 \times 10^{3}}{980.39 \times 9.81} [/latex] [latex] =31.33+0.45-1-2.56 [/latex] [latex] =28.22 \mathrm{m} \approx 28 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 169 A large hydraulic turbine is to generate 300 kW at 1000 rpm under a head of 40 m. For initial testing, a 1:4 scale model of the turbine operates under a head of 10 m. The power generated by the model (in kW) will be
solution: Given data: For Prototype Power generated, [latex] \begin{aligned} & P_{p}=300 \mathrm{kW} \\ \text { Speed: } & N_{p}=1000 \mathrm{rpm} \\ \text { Head: } & H_{p}=40 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] For Model Power generated, [latex] \begin{aligned} & P_{m}=? \\ \text { Head: } & H_{m}=10 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Scale ratio: } & \frac{D_{p}}{D_{m}}=4 \end{aligned}[/latex] We know that the head coefficient, [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{H} &=\frac{g H}{N^{2} D^{2}} \\\left(C_{H}\right)_{m} &=\left(C_{H}\right)_{p} \\\left(\frac{g H}{N^{2} D^{2}}\right)_{m} &=\left(\frac{g H}{N^{2} D^{2}}\right)_{p} \\ \frac{H_{m}}{N_{m}^{2} D_{m}^{2}} &=\frac{H_{p}}{N_{p}^{2} D_{p}^{2}} \\ \frac{H_{m}}{H_{p}}\left(\frac{D_{p}}{D_{m}}\right)^{2} &=\frac{\left(N_{m}\right)^{2}}{N_{p}^{2}} \\ \frac{10}{40}(4)^{2} &=\frac{N_{m}^{2}}{(100)^{2}}\\ \text{or }\quad N_{m}^{2}=4000000\\ \text{or} \quad N_{m}=2000 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Power roefficient [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{p} &=\frac{P}{\rho N^{3} D^{5}} \\\left(C_{P}\right)_{m} &=\left(C_{P}\right)_{p} \\\left(\frac{p}{p N^{3} D^{5}}\right)_{m}&=\left(\frac{P}{\rho N^{3} D^{5}}\right)_{p} \\ \frac{P_{m}}{M_{m}^{3} D_{m}^{5}} &=\frac{P_{P}}{N_{P}^{3} D_{P}^{5}} \because \rho=\text { constant } \\ P_{m} &=P_{P}\left(\frac{N_{m}}{N_{p}}\right)^{3}\left(\frac{D_{m}}{D_{p}}\right)^{5} \\ &=300\left(\frac{2000}{1000}\right)^{3}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{5} \\ &=2.34 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 170 A siphon draws water from a reservoir and discharges it out at atmospheric pressure. Assuming ideal fluid and the reservoir is large, the velocity at point P in the siphon tube is:
solution: Appling Bernoulli's equation at points(1) and (2), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1}&=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1} \\ \text { where } \quad \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}&=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}=\frac{p_{\text {atm }}}{\rho g} \\ \quad z_{1}&=h_{2}-h_{1} \\ \quad z_{2}&=0 \\ \quad V_{1}&=0 \\ \therefore \frac{p_{\text {atm }}}{\rho g}+0&+h_{2}-h_{1}=\frac{p_{\text {am }}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g} \\ \text { or } \quad \frac{v_{2}^{2}}{2 g}&=h_{2}-h_{1}\\ or V_{2}&=\sqrt{2 g\left(h_{2}-h_{1}\right)}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] As constant diameter the siphon tube, the velocity of water inside the siphon tube is same.

question:
Question 171 The velocity profile in fully developed laminar flow in a pipe of diameter D is given by [latex]u=u_{0}(1-4r^{2}/D^{2})[/latex]
 where r is the radial distance from the center. If the viscosity of the fluid is [latex]\mu[/latex], the pressure drop across a length L of the pipe is:
solution: Given velocity profile, [latex] \begin{aligned} u=u_{0}\left(1-\frac{u r^{2}}{D^{2}}\right) \\ \text { At } r=0, u=u_{\max } \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore u_{\max }=u_{0}[/latex] We know that the pressure drop across a length of the pipe, [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1}-p_{2} &=\frac{32 \mu \bar{u} L}{D^{2}} \\ \text{where}\quad \bar{u} &=\text { Average velocity } \\ \bar{u} &=\frac{u_{\max }}{2} \\ \bar{u} &=\frac{u_{0}}{2}\\ \therefore \quad p_{1}-p_{2}&=\frac{32 \mu u_{0} L}{2 \times D^{2}}=\frac{16 \mu u_{0} L}{D^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 172 A two-dimensional flow field has velocities along the x and y directions given by [latex]u=x^{2}t[/latex]
 and [latex]v= -2xyt[/latex]
 respectively, where t is time. The equation of streamlines is:
solution: Equation of streamline, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d x}{u} &=\frac{d y}{v} \\ \frac{d x}{x y} &=\frac{d y}{-2 x y} \\ \frac{d x}{x} &=\frac{d y}{-2 y} \\ 2 \frac{d x}{x}+\frac{d y}{y} &=0 \\ 2 \log _{e} x+\log _{e} y &=\log _{e} c \\ \log _{e} y x^{2} &=\log _{e} c \\ x^{2} y &=c \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 173 In a Pelton wheel, the bucket peripheral speed is 10 m/s, the water jet velocity is 25 m/s and volumetric flow rate of the jet is  [latex]0.1 m^{3}/s[/latex]. 
 If the jet deflection angle is [latex]120^{\circ}[/latex]
 and the flow is ideal, the owe developed is:
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} u &=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{i} &=25 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ Q &=0.1 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Jet deflection angle [latex]=\;120^{0}[/latex] [latex] \beta=180^{\circ}-120^{\circ}=60^{\circ}[/latex] Power developed by Pelton wheel, [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=\rho Q\left(V_{i}-u\right)(1+\cos \beta) u \\ &=1000 \times 0.1(25-10)\left(1+\cos 60^{\circ}\right) \times 10 & \\ &=22500 \mathrm{W}=22.5 \mathrm{kW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 174 In a two-dimensional velocity field with velocities u and v along the x and y directions respectively, the convective acceleration along the x-direction is given by
solution: Convective acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity due to change of position of fluid particle in a fluid flow. Convective acceleration along the x -direction is given by [latex] a_{x}=\frac{d u}{d t}=u \frac{d u}{d y}+v \frac{d u}{d y}+w \frac{d u}{d z} [/latex] for 3-Dvelocity field [latex]=u \frac{d u}{d y}+v \frac{d u}{d y} [/latex] for 2-D (x and y direction) velocity field

question: Question 175 For a Newtonian fluid
solution: For a Newtonian fluid [latex] \tau \propto \frac{d u}{d y} [/latex] [latex] \tau=\mu \frac{d u}{d y}[/latex] where [latex] \quad \tau= [/latex] shear stress [latex] \frac{d u}{d y}= [/latex] rate of shear strain

options.A: shear stress is proportional to shear strain
options.B: rate of shear stress is proportional to shear strain

question:
Question 176 A leaf is caught in a whirlpool. At a given instant, the leaf is at a distance of 120 m from the center of the whirlpool. The whirlpool can be described by the following velocity distribution: [latex]V_{r}= - \left ( \frac{60 \times 10^{3}}{2\pi r} \right )m/s[/latex]
and [latex]V_{0}= \frac{300 \times 10^{3}}{2\pi r} m/s[/latex],
 where r (in meters) is the distance from the center of the whirlpool. What will be the distance of the leaf from the center when it has moved through half a revolution?
solution: [latex]\text{Radial distance }=120 \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] V_{r}=-\frac{60 \times 10^{3}}{2 \pi r} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] [latex] \text{and }\quad V_{\theta}=\frac{300 \times 10^{3}}{2 \pi r} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] [latex] \text{Let }\quad \theta= \text{ Angle turned by a leaf }[/latex] [latex] \text{For }\quad \theta=\frac{1}{2} \text{ revolution }[/latex] [latex] \text{i.e., }\quad \theta=\frac{2 \pi}{2} [/latex] [latex] \theta=\pi \text{ radian}[/latex] [latex] \frac{V_{r}}{V_{\theta}}=-\frac{60 \times 10^{3}}{2 \pi r} \times \frac{2 \pi r}{300 \times 10^{3}}=-\frac{1}{5} [/latex] or [latex]  V_{\theta}=-V_{r} [/latex] We know that [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{r}&=\frac{d r}{d t} \qquad\ldots(i)\\ \text{and }\quad V_{\theta}&=r \omega=r \frac{d \theta}{d t} \\ -5 V_{r}&=r \frac{d \theta}{d t} \\ \text{or }\quad V_{r}&=-\frac{r}{5} \frac{d \theta}{d t} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Equating Eq. (i) and Eq. (ii), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d r}{d t}&=-\frac{r}{5} \frac{d \theta}{d t} \\ \text{or }\quad \frac{d r}{r}&=-\frac{d \theta}{5} \qquad\ldots(i)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Intgegrating both sides, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \int_{120}^{1} \frac{d r}{r}&=-\frac{1}{5} \int_{0}^{\pi} d \theta \\ \left[\log _{\theta} r\right]_{120}^{r}&=-\frac{1}{5}[\theta]_{0}^{\pi} \\ \log _{e} r-\log _{e} 120&=-\frac{\pi}{5} \\ \log _{e}\frac{r}{120}&=-\frac{\pi}{5} \\ \text{or }\quad \frac{r}{120}&=e^{-\frac{\pi}{5}} \\ \text{or }\quad r=120 \times e^{-\frac{\pi}{5}}&=\frac{120}{e^{3.14 / 5}}=64 \mathrm{m} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 177 A U-tube manometer with a small quantity of mercury is used to measure the static pressure difference between two locations A and B in a conical section through which an incompressible fluid flows. At a particular flow rate, the mercury column appears as shown in the figure. The density of mercury is 13600 [latex]kg/m^{3}[/latex]
 and g = 9.81 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex]. Which of the following is correct?
solution: Flow direction is A to B because pressure at section A is more than at section B. [latex]p_{A}-p_{B}=(\rho g h)_{H g}=\rho_{H g} g h_{H g} [/latex] where, [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho_{\mathrm{Hg}} &=13600 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ g &=9.81 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ h_{\mathrm{Hg}} &=150 \mathrm{mm}=0.15 \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore p_{\mathrm{A}}-p_{B} &=13600 \times 9.81 \times 0.15 \\ &=20012.4 \mathrm{Pa}=20.01 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A:

 = 20 kPa

question: Question 178 A venturimeter of 20 mm throat diameter is used to measure the velocity of water in a horizontal pipe of 40 mm diameter. If the pressure difference between the pipe and throat sections is found to be 30 kPa then, neglecting frictional losses, the flow velocity is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} d_{2}&=20 \mathrm{mm}=0.02 \mathrm{m} \\ d_{1}&=40 \mathrm{mm}=0.04 \mathrm{m} \\ \Delta p&=p_{1}-p_{2}=30 \mathrm{kPa}=30 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{Pa} \end{aligned}[/latex] For continuity equation, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{1} V_{1} &=A_{2} V_{2} \\ V_{2} &=\frac{A_{1}}{A_{2}} V_{1}=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4} d_{1}^{2}}{\frac{\pi}{4} d_{2}^{2}} \times V_{1} \\ &=\left(\frac{d_{1}}{d_{2}}\right)^{2} V_{1}=\left(\frac{0.04}{0.02}\right)^{2} V_{1} \\ V_{2} &=4 V_{1} \qquad\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying Bernoulli's equation, we get [latex] \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1}=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{2}[/latex] For horizontal pipe, [latex] \begin{aligned} z_{1} &=z_{2} \\ \frac{p_{1}-p_{2}}{\rho g} &=\frac{v_{2}^{2}-v_{1}^{2}}{2 g} \\ \frac{\Delta p}{\rho} &=\frac{1}{2}\left(v_{2}^{2}-v_{1}^{2}\right) \\ \frac{30 \times 10^{3}}{1000} &=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(4 v_{1}\right)^{2}-v_{1}^{2}\right] \\ \frac{15 V_{1}^{2}}{2} &=30 \\ v_{1}^{2} &=4 \\ \text{or }\qquad v_{1} &=2 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 181 At a hydro electric power plant site, available head and flow rate are 24.5 m and 10.1 [latex]m^3[/latex]/s respectively. If the turbine to be installed is required to run at 4.0 revolution per second (rps) with an overall efficiency of 90%, the suitable type of turbine for this site is
solution: Given data: Available head, [latex] H=24.5 \mathrm{m} [/latex] [latex] \text { Discharge: } Q=10.1 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] [latex] \text { Speed: } N=4 \mathrm{rps}=4 \times 60 \mathrm{rpm}=240 \mathrm{rom}[/latex] Overall efficiency, [latex] \eta_{0}=90 \%=0.90 [/latex] [latex] \text{also }\eta_{0}=\frac{P}{\rho Q g H}[/latex] [latex] 0.90=\frac{P}{1000 \times 10.1 \times 9.81 \times 24.5}[/latex] [latex] or \quad P=2184736.05 \mathrm{W}=2184.73 \mathrm{kW}[/latex] Specific speed, [latex] N_{s}=\frac{N \sqrt{P}}{H^{5 / 4}}[/latex] where P is in [latex] \mathrm{kW} [/latex] Nis in rpm[/latex] H is in m [latex] \therefore N_{s}=\frac{240 \times \sqrt{2184.76}}{(24.5)^{5 / 4}}[/latex] [latex] =205.80(\mathrm{Sl} \text { unit })[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] As the specific speed lies between 51-255 , the turbine is Francis.

question:
Question 182 The pressure gauges [latex]G_{1}[/latex]
 and [latex]G_{2}[/latex]
 installed on the system show pressures of [latex]P_{G1}[/latex]
 = 5.00 bar and [latex]P_{G2}[/latex]
=1.00 bar. The value of unknown pressure P is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{G_{1}}&=5 \text { bar } \\ P_{G_{2}}&=1 \text { bar } \\ P_{\text {atm }}&=1.01 \text { bar } \end{aligned}[/latex] For pressure gauge [latex]G_{2}[/latex] Absolute pressure [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\text { Atmospheric pr. }+\text { Gauge pr. } \\ p_{\text {abs }} &=p_{\text {atn }}+p_{G 2}=1.01+1=1.01 \text { bar }\\ &= \text{ Local atmospheric pr. for pr. gauge }G_{1} \\ &=\left(p_{\text {atm }}\right) \end{aligned}[/latex] For pressure gauge [latex]G_{1} [/latex] Absolute pressure = Local atm. pr. + Gauge pr. [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=\left(P_{\mathrm{atm}}\right)_{1}+P G_{1} \\ &=2.01+5=7.01 \mathrm{bar} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 183 A centrifugal pump is required to pump water to an open water tank situated 4 km away from the location of the pump through a pipe of diameter 0.2 m having Darcy's friction factor of 0.01. The average speed of water in the pipe is 2 m/s. If it is maintain a constant head of 5 m in the tank, neglecting other minor losses, the absolute discharge pressure at the pump exit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} l &=4 \mathrm{km}=4000 \mathrm{m} \\ d &=0.2 \mathrm{m} \\ f &=0.01 \\ V &=2 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ h &=5 \mathrm{m} \\ h_{f} &=\frac{f l V^{2}}{2 g d}=\frac{0.01 \times 4000 \times(2)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.2} \\ &=40.77 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Head produced by the pump, [latex] \begin{aligned} H &=h+h_{f} \\ &=5+40.77=45.77 \mathrm{m} \text { of water } \end{aligned}[/latex] Absolute discharge pressure at the pump exit [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{\text {abs }}&=\rho g H+p_{\text {atm }} \\ &=1000 \times 9.81 \times 45.77 \mathrm{Pa} \\ &=5.503 \mathrm{bar} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 184 For air flow over a flat plate, velocity (U) and boundary layer thickness ([latex]\delta[/latex]) can be expressed respectively, as [latex]\frac{U}{U_{a}}=\frac{3}{2}\frac{y}{\delta }-\frac{1}{2}\left ( \frac{y}{\delta } \right )^{3}; \delta =\frac{4.64x}{\sqrt{Re_{x}}}[/latex] If the free stream velocity is 2m/s, and air has kinematic viscosity of [latex]1.5\times 10^{-5}m^{2}/s[/latex]
 and density of [latex]1.23 kg/m^{3}[/latex], the wall shear stress at x = 1m, is
solution: Reynold number [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Re}_{x}=\frac{u_{\infty} x}{u}=\frac{2 \times 1}{1.5 \times 10^{-5}}=1.33 \times 10^{5} \\ \delta=\frac{4.64 x}{\sqrt{\mathrm{Re}_{x}}}=\frac{4.64 \times 1}{\sqrt{1.33 \times 10^{5}}}=0.0127 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \text{Now, }\frac{d u}{d y}=u_{\infty}\left[\frac{3}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{\delta}-\frac{3}{2}\left(\frac{y^{2}}{\delta^{3}}\right)\right][/latex] [latex] \left.\frac{d u}{d y}\right|_{y=0}=\frac{3 u_{\infty}}{2 \delta}[/latex] Now, shear stress, [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau_{0} &=\mu\left(\frac{d u}{d y}\right)_{y=0}=\mu \times \frac{3 u_{\infty}}{2 \delta} \\ &=\frac{3 u_{\infty} \times v \times \rho}{2 \delta} \quad \because \mu=v \rho \\ &=\frac{3 \times 2 \times 1.5 \times 10^{-5} \times 1.23}{2 \times 0.0127} \\ &=4.36 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 185 A closed cylinder having a radius R and height H is filled with oil density [latex]\rho[/latex]. If the cylinder is rotated about its axis at an angular velocity of  [latex]\omega[/latex], the thrust at the bottom of the cylinder is
solution: We know that [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial p}{\partial r}&=\frac{\rho v^{2}}{r}=\rho \omega^{2} r \\ \Rightarrow \quad \int_{0}^{p} \partial p&=\int_{0}^{f} \rho \omega^{2} r d r\\ \therefore \quad p&=\frac{\rho \omega^{2} r^{2}}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Area of circular ring[latex] =2 \pi r d r [/latex] Force on elementary ring = Intensity of pressure x Area of ring [latex] =\frac{\rho}{2} \omega^{2} r^{2} 2 \pi r d r[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex] Total force on the bottom of the cylinder due to rotation [latex] \begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{R} \frac{\rho \omega^{2} r^{2}}{2} \cdot 2 \pi r d r &=\frac{\rho}{2} \omega^{2} \cdot 2 \pi \int_{0}^{R} r^{3} d r \\ &=\pi \omega^{2} \rho\left[\frac{r^{4}}{4}\right]_{0}^{R} \\ &=\rho \omega^{2} \cdot \frac{\pi R^{4}}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex] Thrust at the bottom of the cylinder = weight  of water in cylinder or force due to hydrostatic pressure + total force on the top of cylinder due to rotation [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\rho g \times \pi R^{2} \times H+\rho \omega^{2} \times \frac{\pi R^{4}}{4} \\ &=\pi R^{2}\left[\frac{\rho \omega^{2} R^{2}}{4}+\rho g H\right] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 186 For a fluid flow through a divergent pipe of length L having inlet and outlet radii and [latex]R_{1}[/latex]
 and [latex]R_{2}[/latex]
 respectively and a constant flow rate of Q, assuming the velocity to be axial and uniform at any cross section, the acceleration at the exit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &a_{x}=u \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+v \frac{\partial u}{\partial y}+w \frac{\partial u}{\partial z}+\frac{\partial u}{\partial t}\\ &\therefore \quad a_{x}=u \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\\ &Q=A u \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{or }\quad u&=\frac{Q}{A} \\ u&=\frac{Q}{\pi \mathrm{R}^{2}} \\ R &= R_{1}+\frac{R_{2}-R_{1}}{L} \cdot x \\ let,\\ R_{1}&=a\text{ and } \frac{R_{2}-R_{1}}{L}=b \\ \therefore \quad R&=a+b x \\ u &=\frac{Q}{\pi(a+b x)^{2}} \\ \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} &=\frac{-2 b Q}{\pi(a+b x)^{3}} \\ a_{x} &=u \frac{\partial u}{\partial x} \\ a_{x=L} &=\left.u \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}\right|_{x=L} \end{aligned} [/latex] and also replacing a and b [latex] a_{x=L}=\frac{-2 Q^{2}\left(R_{1}-R_{2}\right)}{\pi^{2} L R_{2}^{5}}[/latex]

question:
Question 188 A fluid flow is represented by the velocity field [latex]\bar{V}=ax+\bar{i}+ay\bar{j}[/latex]
 where a is a constant. The equation of streamline passing through a point (1,2) is
solution: Given: [latex]\vec{V}=a x \hat{i}+a y \hat{j}[/latex] [latex] \text{i.e. }\quad \;u=a x \text { and } v=a y[/latex] Equation of stream line is given by [latex] \frac{d x}{u}=\frac{d y}{v}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \frac{d x}{a x}=\frac{d y}{a y}[/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad \frac{d x}{x}=\frac{d y}{y}[/latex] Integrating both sides, we get [latex] lnx=\ln y+\ln c[/latex] (where c is constant of integration) [latex] \therefore x=c y[/latex] since the stream line passed through point (1,2) therefore [latex] 1=2 c [/latex] [latex] c=1 / 2[/latex] Hence equation of stream line is [latex] x=\frac{1}{2} y[/latex] [latex] \text{or }\quad 2 x-y=0[/latex]

question: Question 189 An incompressible fluid (kinematic viscosity, [latex]7.4\times 10^{-7} m^{2}/s[/latex], specific gravity, 0.88) is held between two parallel plates. If the top late is moved with a velocity of 0.5 m/s while the bottom one is held stationary, the fluid attains a linear velocity profile in the gap of 0.5 mm between these plates; the shear stress in Pascals on the surface of top plate is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} v&=7.4 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{m}^{2} / \mathrm{s} \\ S&=0.88\\ \therefore \qquad \rho&=1000 \times 0.88=880 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ U&=0.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ h&=0.5 \mathrm{mm}=0.0005 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] Dynamic viscosity, [latex] \begin{aligned} \mu &=\rho v=880 \times 7.4 \times 10^{-7} \\ &=6.512 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{Ns} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ \text { Shear stress: } \tau &=u \frac{d u}{d y} \\ \text { where } d u&=u-0=0.5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ d y &=h=0.0005 \mathrm{m}\\ \therefore \quad \tau &=\frac{6.512 \times 10^{-3} \times 0.5}{0.0005} \\ &=0.651 \mathrm{Pa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 190 A syringe with a frictionless plunger contacts water and has its end a 100mm longer needle of 1mm diameter .The internal diameter of the syringe is 10mm. Water density is [latex]1000kg/m^{3}[/latex]. The plunger is pushed in at 10 mm/s and the water comes out as a jet Neglect losses in the cylinder and assume fully developed laminar viscous flow throughout the needle; the Darcy friction factor is 64/Re. Where Re is the Reynolds number. Give that the viscosity of water is [latex]1.0\times 10^{-3}[/latex]
 kg/s m , the force F in Newton required on the plunger is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \operatorname{Re} &=\frac{\rho V_{2} d_{2}}{\mu}=\frac{1000 \times 1 \times 0.001}{1 \times 10^{-3}} \\ &=1000 \end{aligned}\\ \text{Now Darcy's friction factor},\\ f=\frac{64}{\operatorname{Re}}=\frac{64}{1000}=0.064\\ \text{Head loss in needle,} \\ \begin{aligned} h_{f} &=\frac{f L V^{2}}{2 g d}=\frac{0.064 \times 0.1 \times(1)^{2}}{2 \times 9.81 \times 0.001} \\ &=0.3262 \mathrm{m} \text { of water } \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying Bernoulli's equation at points and we get [latex] \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1}=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{2}+h_{f} [/latex] [latex]\text{since }\quad z_{1}=z_{2} [/latex] [latex] \text{and }\quad p_{2}=0 \qquad (atmospheric)[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g} &=\left(\frac{V_{2}^{2}-V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}\right)+h_{f} \\ p_{1} &=\frac{\rho}{2}\left(V_{2}^{2}-V_{1}^{2}\right)+\rho g h_{f} \\ &=\frac{1000}{2}\left[(1)^{2}-(0.01)^{2}\right] \\ &+1000 \times 9.81 \times 0.3262 \\ &=3699.97 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Force required on plunger, [latex] =p_{1} \times A_{1}=3699.97 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(0.01)^{2}\\ =0.29 \mathrm{N}[/latex]

question: Question 191 A syringe with a frictionless plunger contacts water and has its end a 100mm longer needle of 1mm diameter .The internal diameter of the syringe is 10mm. Water density is [latex]1000kg/m^{3}[/latex]. The plunger is pushed in at 10 mm/s and the water comes out as a jet Assuming ideal flow, the force F in Newton required on the plunger to push out the water is
solution: Applying continuity equation at sections 1 and 2 we get [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{1} v_{1} &=A_{2} V_{2} \\ v_{2} &=\left(\frac{A_{1}}{A_{2}}\right) v_{1} \\ v_{2} &=\frac{\frac{\pi}{4} \times(0.01)^{2}}{\frac{\pi}{4} \times(0.001)^{2}} \times 0.01 \\ &=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying Bernoulli's equation at sections 1 and 2 we get [latex] \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{v_{1}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{1}=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{2} [/latex] since [latex]\quad z_{1}=z_{2} [/latex] and taking gauge pressure [latex]\begin{aligned} p_{2} &=0 \quad (atmospheric)\\ \therefore \quad \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g} &=\frac{V_{2}^{2}-V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}\\ p_{1} &=\frac{\rho}{2}\left(V_{2}^{2}-V_{1}^{2}\right) \\ &=\frac{1000}{2}\left[(1)^{2}-(0.01)^{2}\right] \\ &=499.95 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\\ &\text{Force required on plunger},\\ &=p_{1} \times A_{1}=499.95 \times \frac{\pi}{4} \times(0.01)^{2} \\ &=0.039 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]
